input: To develop a straightforward mouse model of lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced pulpitis that mimics the progression of inflammation in dental pulp. Available materials: C57BL/6 mice, tribromoethanol, LPS-Pg, paraformaldehyde, decalcification solution, embedding reagents, histological staining solutions. How to prepare, model, analyze, and visualize LPS-induced pulpitis in mice?
output: 1. Preparation.
1.1 Prepare Recipes 1–8 following the instructions provided in the Recipes section.
1.2 Autoclaving of the modeling instruments: Within 1–5 days before modeling, place the modeling instruments in a stainless-steel lunch box and sterilize them using an autoclave.
2. Modeling Surgery.
2.1 Anesthesia.
2.1.1 Weigh the C57BL/6 mouse using a beaker and an electronic scale with 0.1g accuracy.
2.1.2 Use 1.2% tribromoethanol (see Recipes) for anesthesia (intraperitoneal injection), with a dosage of 0.5mL per 20g body weight.
2.2 Fixing.
2.2.1 Pinch the mouse’s toe to check its reaction.
2.2.2 Secure the mouse to the surgical pad with medical adhesive tape; this will ensure that the mouse cannot interrupt the surgery.
2.3 Opening the Pulp Chamber.
2.3.1 Open the mouse’s oral cavity with curved ophthalmic forceps.
2.3.2 Use dressing forceps to expand the oral cavity and protect the tongue, thus preventing injury by the diamond bur; concurrently, completely expose the upper portion of the mouth.
2.3.3 Use the diamond bur to access the maxillary first molar in the mouse, then expand the pulp exposure with the dental file; the final diameter of exposure should be approximately 1mm.
2.4 Rinsing.
2.4.1 Aspirate 0.1mL of 0.9% NaCl solution (see Recipes) with a 1mL injection syringe.
2.4.2 Place the tip of the needle over the medullary foramen and quickly empty the syringe to flush out any dentin debris that may have entered the medullary foramen.
2.5 LPS Induction.
2.5.1 Extract 10uL of 1mg/mL LPS-Pg (see Recipes) into a 0.1mL centrifuge tube.
2.5.2 Use straight ophthalmic forceps to completely saturate a small cotton ball in the LPS-Pg solution.
2.5.3 Keep the saturated small cotton ball on the exposed pulp for 5min.
2.6 Pulp Capping and Tooth Filling.
2.6.1 Remove the cotton ball and restore the tooth with Esthet-X flow.
2.6.2 After surgery, loosen the mouse’s restraints; return the mouse to the cage after it has awakened.
3. Tissue Decalcification and Paraffin Embedding.
3.1 Sample Collection.
3.1.1 Sacrifice the mouse by cervical dislocation; carefully harvest maxillary tissue with straight ophthalmic forceps tweezers and ophthalmic scissors.
3.1.2 Place the maxillary tissues into a 15mL centrifuge tube with 10% paraformaldehyde fixative (neutral) and incubate at room temperature for 24h.
3.2 Decalcification.
3.2.1 Place printed labels and tissues in sequential order in an embedding frame.
3.2.2 Then, place them in a basin, fill it with fresh decalcification solution, seal the container, and store all components in a constant temperature shaker at 25°C with a speed of 110 RPM.
3.3 Dehydration and Wax Infiltration.
3.3.1 Remove the softened tissue from the decalcification solution, rinse with tap water for 5h, place it into a dehydrating basket, and dehydrate using an alcohol gradient in the dehydrator.

3.3.2 Prepare reagents for dehydration and wax infiltration: alcohol (75%, 85%, 90%, 95%), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III), benzyl alcohol, xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and melted paraffin (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III).
3.4 Embedding.
3.4.1 Transfer the wax-infiltrated tissue to the embedding machine.

3.4.2 First, place the melted wax into the embedding frame. Then, place the tissue into the embedding frame according to the requirements of the embedding surface, and attach appropriate labels before the wax solidifies.
4. Sectioning.
4.1 Use the trimmed wax block to prepare 4um thick paraffin sections.
4.2 Float sections in warm water at 40°C to flatten the tissue.
4.3 Collect the sections and bake them in an oven at 60°C.
5. HE Staining.
5.1 Dewaxing and Rehydration.

5.1.1 Prepare reagents: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and 75% ethyl alcohol.

5.1.2 Immerse paraffin sections in the following sequence: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution I for 20 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution II for 20min, anhydrous ethanol I for 5min, anhydrous ethanol II for 5min, and 75% ethyl alcohol for 5min.
5.2 Hematoxylin Staining.
5.2.1 Stain the sections with hematoxylin solution for 3-5 min and rinse with tap water.
5.2.2 Next, immerse the sections in hematoxylin differentiation solution and rinse with tap water.
5.2.3 Finally, immerse the sections in hematoxylin bluing solution and rinse with tap water.
5.3 Eosin Staining.
5.3.1 Immerse sections in the following sequence of solutions: 85% ethanol for 5min, 95% ethanol for 5min, and eosin dye for 5min.
5.4 Dehydration and Sealing.

5.4.1 Prepare reagents for dehydration and wax infiltration: absolute ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III) and xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II).
5.4.2 Immerse sections in the following sequence of solutions: absolute ethanol I for 5min, absolute ethanol II for 5min, absolute ethanol III for 5min, xylene I for 5min, and xylene II for 5min.
6. Immunofluorescence Staining.
6.1 Dewaxing and Rehydration.

6.1.1 Prepare reagents: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III) and anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into three separate bottles labeled I, II, and III).

6.1.2 Sequentially immerse the sections in the following sequence: environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution I for 10 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution II for 10 min, environmentally friendly dewaxing and clearing solution III for 10 min, absolute ethanol I for 5 min, absolute ethanol II for 5min, and absolute ethanol III for 5min.
6.2 Antigen Retrieval.
6.2.1 Place the sections in a water bath for 30min.
6.2.2 After retrieval is complete, allow sections to cool naturally.
6.3 Serum Blocking.
6.3.1 Dry the sections and use a hydrophobic pen to draw a circle around the tissue.
6.3.2 Apply 3% BSA for 30min to block nonspecific binding.
6.4 Primary Antibody Incubation.
6.4.1 Prepare primary antibody: dilute the primary antibodies (DSPP 1:100; MPO 1:500) in PBS buffer.
6.4.2 Add the diluted primary antibody to the sections, ensuring that they are lying flat in a humidified chamber.
6.5 Secondary Antibody Incubation.
6.5.1 Wash the sections three times in PBS (pH7.4) on a decolorization shaker for 5min per wash.
6.5.2 Add the secondary antibody (Cy3-labeled goat anti-mouse IgG) and incubate for 50min at room temperature in the dark.
6.6 Stain Cell Nuclei with DAPI.
6.6.1 Wash the sections three times in PBS (pH7.4) on a decolorization shaker for 5min per wash.
6.6.2 Add the DAPI staining reagent and incubate for 10min at room temperature in the dark.
6.7 Quench Tissue Autofluorescence and Sealing.
6.7.1 Wash the sections three times in PBS (pH7.4) on a decolorization shaker for 5min per wash.
6.7.2 Add tissue autofluorescence quenching agent B and incubate for 10min at room temperature in the dark.
7. Goldner Trichrome Staining.
7.1 Dewaxing and Rehydration.
7.1.1 Prepare reagents: Xylene (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), anhydrous ethanol (divide the liquid into two separate bottles labeled I and II), and 75% ethyl alcohol.

7.1.2 Sequentially immerse the paraffin sections in the following sequence: xylene I for 20 min, xylene II for 20 min, anhydrous ethanol I for 5min, anhydrous ethanol II for 5min, and 75% ethyl alcohol for 5min.
7.2 Nuclear Staining.
7.2.1 Mix Goldner staining solution A and Goldner staining solution B in equal proportions.
7.2.2 Place sections in the mixed solution and stain for 20min.
7.3 Staining with Goldner Staining Solution C.
7.3.1 Immerse sections in the first jar of Goldner staining solution C for 10min.
7.3.2 Quickly rinse with 0.2% glacial acetic acid (3 s per rinse).
7.4 Staining with Goldner Staining Solution D.
7.4.1 Immerse sections in Goldner staining solution D for 3 min.
7.4.2 Monitor the staining under a microscope; ensure that Goldner staining solution C fades from the collagen areas.
7.5 Staining with Goldner Staining Solution C.
7.5.1 Immerse sections in the second jar of Goldner staining solution C for 5min.
7.5.2 Quickly rinse with 0.2% glacial acetic acid (3 s per rinse).
7.6 Staining with Goldner Staining Solution E.
7.6.1 Immerse sections in Goldner staining solution E for 5min.
7.6.2 Then, differentiate the stain using three jars of 0.2% glacial acetic acid (2 s per jar).
7.7 Clearing and Sealing.
7.7.1 Place sections in the third jar of anhydrous ethanol for 5min.
7.7.2 Clear the sections in xylene for 5 min.
8. Perform Microscopy Examination, Image Acquisition, and Analysis.
8.1 HE staining: Nuclei will be stained blue, whereas cytoplasm will be stained red.

8.2 Immunofluorescence staining: DAPI (excitation wavelength 330-380 nm, emission wavelength 420nm) will stain nuclei blue, whereas Cy3 (excitation wavelength 510-560nm, mission wavelength 590nm) will stain the target protein red.
8.3 Goldner trichrome staining: mineralized bone will be stained green, whereas non-mineralized tissue will be stained orange red.

system_prompt: As an expert in biochemical and molecular functional analysis, specializing in in-gel activity assays of mitochondrial and cytosolic aconitases, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To simultaneously monitor mitochondrial and cytosolic aconitase activities (ACO2 and ACO1) as surrogate markers of compartment-specific oxidative stress and iron status. Available materials: cell cultures, human and mouse tissues, protein extraction buffers (Triton-citrate, RIPA-citrate), non-denaturing PAGE system, Bradford Protein Assay, and aconitase activity assay reagents. How to prepare extracts, perform non-denaturing PAGE, and conduct in-gel aconitase activity staining?
output: 1. Prepare Cell Culture Extracts.
1.1 Harvest and Wash Cell Pellets.
1.1.1 Harvest cell cultures and wash cell pellets 3× with PBS at 4°C.
1.1.2 Lyse the cell pellets for analysis immediately or flash-freeze cell pellets on dry ice.
1.1.3 Store cell pellets at -80°C until use.
1.2 Lysis and Extraction.
1.2.1 Lyse cell pellets using Triton-citrate or RIPA-citrate extraction buffer at 4°C.
1.2.2 Add 1-2 v/v of Triton-citrate or RIPA-citrate extraction buffer to each cell pellet.
1.2.3 Disperse cells using a pipette and incubate on ice for 10 min with intermittent agitation.
1.2.4 Centrifuge at >16,000×g for 5 min in a refrigerated microcentrifuge and collect the supernatant (protein extract).
1.3 Protein Quantification.
1.3.1 Proceed with protein quantification using Bradford Protein Assay from Bio-Rad.
1.3.2 Follow the manufacturer's protocol for protein quantification.
2. Prepare Tissue Extracts.
2.1 Harvest and Prepare Tissue.
2.1.1 Harvest tissues, cut into small pieces, and flash-freeze on dry ice.
2.1.2 Store at -80°C until use.
2.2 Homogenization.
2.2.1 Chill microcentrifuge tubes containing 100µL of homogenization beads on dry ice.
2.2.2 Weight out 20-40mg of tissue pieces in the microcentrifuge tubes containing the homogenization beads.
2.2.3 Add 5µL of cold RIPA-citrate extract buffer per milligram of tissue to each tube.
2.2.4 Run the Bullet Blender for 2 min at speed 8 at 4°C, wait for 2 min, and repeat once.
2.3 Centrifugation and Extraction.
2.3.1 Centrifuge at 2,000×g for 2 min in a refrigerated microcentrifuge and transfer the supernatant into chilled microcentrifuge tubes.
2.3.2 Centrifuge at maximum speed (21,000×g) for 10 min at 4°C and transfer the supernatant (tissue RIPA extract) to chilled microcentrifuge tubes.
2.3.3 Use immediately or store at -80°C until use.
2.4 Protein Quantification.
2.4.1 Proceed with protein quantification using Bradford Protein Assay from Bio-Rad.
2.4.2 Follow the manufacturer's protocol for protein quantification.
3. Non-Denaturing Polyacrylamide Gel Electrophoresis.
3.1 Prepare Running Buffer and Gel.
3.1.1 Prepare 1× running buffer and keep it cold (0-4°C).
3.1.2 Cast the separating gel and overlay with 0.5 mL of isopropyl alcohol.
3.1.3 Allow polymerization to occur for 15 min at RT and then rinse out the alcohol.
3.2 Cast Stacking Gel and Assemble Electrophoresis Cell.
3.2.1 Cast the stacking gel and insert the well-forming comb without trapping air under the teeth.
3.2.2 Assemble the electrophoresis cell and fill the inner and outer buffer chambers with cold running buffer.
3.3 Load Samples and Run Electrophoresis.
3.3.1 Mix the protein extract with the appropriate amount of loading buffer and deionized H2O.
3.3.2 Load samples slowly to allow them to settle evenly on the bottom of the wells.
3.3.3 Run electrophoresis at constant 170 V at 4°C for 2.5-4 h for a mini-gel.
4. In-Gel Aconitase Activity Staining.
4.1 Prepare Aconitase Activity Assay Mix.
4.1.1 Prewarm the H2O for the aconitase activity assay mix.
4.1.2 Add all the assay reagents, except IDH, to the prewarmed H2O.
4.2 Stain the Gel.
4.2.1 Remove the gel carefully from between the glass plates and place the gel in a clean tray.
4.2.2 Add IDH to the aconitase activity assay mix and add to the tray containing the gel.
4.2.3 Incubate with gentle agitation at RT or in a 37°C incubator for 5–60 min.
4.3 Wash and Dry the Gel.
4.3.1 Wash the gel 5–10 times with H2O, with gentle agitation and protection from direct light.
4.3.2 Dry the gel between a filter paper and a plastic wrap using a gel vacuum dryer or air-drying methods.

system_prompt: As an expert in biochemical and molecular functional analysis, specialize in kinase activity assays, protein immunoprecipitation, and radiometric phosphorylation techniques. Demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step coordination while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To measure the kinase activity of wildtype and disease-causing ALPK1 mutants using a cell-free radiometric phosphorylation assay. Available materials: ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue cells, FLAG-tagged ALPK1 constructs, GST-TIFA, radioactive ATP, Bradford protein assay kit, anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin. How to prepare cells, transfect, lyse, immunoprecipitate, and quantify kinase activity?
output: 1. Preparation of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue Cells.
1.1. Prepare two confluent 15-cm dishes of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue cells, no higher than passage 30.
1.2. Ensure the cells are cultured at 37°C with 5% CO2.
2. Transient Expression of FLAG-tagged ALPK1 Constructs.
2.1. Plate 15 million ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue cells into each of 3 × 15-cm dishes.
2.2. Cell Detachment and Counting.
2.2.1. Aspirate the culture media from two confluent 15-cm dishes of cells and replace with 10 mL of PBS.
2.2.2. Aspirate the PBS and add 3 mL of trypsin-EDTA solution to each dish.
2.2.3. Add 15 mL of culture media to each plate and pipette up and down to produce a single-cell suspension.
2.2.4. Count the number of cells using standard methods, ensuring cell viability is at least 90%.
2.3. Transfection of ALPK1 KO HEK-Blue Cells.
2.3.1. Prepare lipofectamine 2000 and OptiMEM for transfection.
2.3.2. Dilute 60 μg of each plasmid in 600 μL of OptiMEM.
2.3.3. Add the diluted lipofectamine 2000 to each diluted plasmid and incubate for 10 minutes at room temperature.
2.3.4. Add each solution dropwise to the relevant dish of cells and return them to the incubator.
2.4. Post-Transfection Cell Culture.
2.4.1. After 4 hours, carefully aspirate the culture media and add 15 mL of fresh culture media.
2.4.2. Return the plates to the incubator for 20 hours.
3. Preparation and Normalization of Cell Extracts.
3.1. Cell Extract Preparation.
3.1.1. Twenty-four hours post-transfection, detach the cells using a serological pipette.
3.1.2. Centrifuge the tubes at 800 × g for 5 minutes at room temperature to pellet the cells.
3.1.3. Wash the cells with PBS and centrifuge again.
3.1.4. Add 1 mL of ice-cold lysis buffer to each cell pellet and pipette up and down until a homogenous suspension is formed.
3.2. Cell Extract Normalization.
3.2.1. Determine the protein concentration in each cell extract using the Bradford protein assay kit.
3.2.2. Dilute the cell extracts to a final concentration of 2 mg/mL protein using ice-cold lysis buffer.
3.2.3. Immunoprecipitate each cell extract using anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin.
3.2.4. Analyze the immunoprecipitated samples by SDS-PAGE and quantify the intensity of each FLAG-ALPK1 mutant.
3.3. Cell Extract Aliquoting and Storage.
3.3.1. Prepare 0.5 mL aliquots of each cell extract on ice.
3.3.2. Snap-freeze the aliquots and store them at -80°C until use.
4. Determination of Linear Rate Conditions for WT ALPK1.
4.1. Time Course Phosphorylation Assays.
4.1.1. Thaw two aliquots of WT FLAG-ALPK1 lysate on ice and combine them.
4.1.2. Prepare anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin slurry and wash the resin with ice-cold lysis buffer.
4.1.3. Resuspend the resin in ice-cold reaction buffer and aliquot into individual microcentrifuge tubes.
4.1.4. Add GST-TIFA and radioactive ATP solution to each tube and incubate at 30°C.
4.2. SDS-PAGE and Scintillation Counting.
4.2.1. Analyze the samples by SDS-PAGE and stain with InstantBlue.
4.2.2. Destain the gel and cut out individual bands corresponding to GST-TIFA.
4.2.3. Count each sample using a scintillation counter and plot the resulting data.
5. Measurement of the Activity of ALPK1 Mutants.
5.1. Endpoint Phosphorylation Assays.
5.1.1. Thaw an aliquot of each cell extract on ice and prepare anti-FLAG M2 affinity resin slurry.
5.1.2. Wash the resin with ice-cold lysis buffer and resuspend in ice-cold reaction buffer.
5.1.3. Add GST-TIFA and radioactive ATP solution to each tube and incubate at 30°C.
5.1.4. Terminate the reactions and analyze the samples by SDS-PAGE.
5.2. Scintillation Counting.
5.2.1. Analyze the incorporation of radioactivity into GST-TIFA by scintillation counting.
5.2.2. Plot the resulting data and compare the activity of ALPK1 mutants.

system_prompt: As an expert in molecular biology protocols, specializing in the development of nucleic acid amplification and lateral flow assays for viral detection, provide a structured approach to the design and optimization of primers and probes for a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) and lateral flow assay (LFA) system targeting Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To design primers and probes for a rapid EBV detection system combining RPA and LFA. Available materials: DNAMAN 8.0 software, blood/cell/tissue genomic DNA extraction kit, NanoDrop microspectrophotometer. How to design primers for both PCR and RPA, optimize probes, and immobilize antibodies on a lateral flow strip?
output: 1. Primer & Probe & Lateral Flow Strip Design.
1.1 General Primer Design.
1.1.1 Download the nucleic acid sequence of EBV from NCBI (Genebank: V01555).
1.1.2 Design PCR and RPA primers for conserved regions using DNAMAN 8.0 software.
1.1.3 Design primers that can participate in both PCR and RPA.
1.2 RPA-LFA Primer & Probe Design.
1.2.1 Select the same amplified fragments as in PCR but with BIOTIN modification at the 5' end of the reverse primer.
1.2.2 Introduce a probe to enhance amplification specificity.
1.2.3 Design the probe with a FITC modification at the 5' end, a modifying group (C3-Spacer) at the 3' end, and tetrahydrofuran (THF) labeled in the middle.
1.3 Lateral Flow Strip Design.
1.3.1 Immobilize gold particles of BIOTIN antibody and FITC antibody on a lateral flow strip (test line).
1.3.2 The target fragment will be captured to appear as a positive band.

system_prompt: As an expert in molecular biology protocols, specializing in the development of nucleic acid amplification and lateral flow assays for viral detection, provide a structured approach to sample preparation for EBV detection using a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) and lateral flow assay (LFA) system.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To prepare samples for EBV detection using RPA-LFA. Available materials: Tiangen Biochemical Technology (Beijing) Co. blood/cell/tissue genomic DNA extraction kit, NanoDrop microspectrophotometer. How to extract and dilute DNA from cells?
output: 1. Sample Preparation.
1.1 DNA Extraction.
1.1.1 Collect cells in good growth condition, centrifuge with trypsin digestion, and aspirate the cell suspension.
1.1.2 Use the blood/cell/tissue genomic DNA extraction kit.
1.1.3 Add 1mL of PBS reagent to keep the cells in suspension, resuspend to rewash the cell precipitate, and centrifuge at 9,306×g for 1min.
1.1.4 Add 200~uL of buffer solution GA, shake the mixture until it is fully suspended, and add 20~uL of proteinase K solution.
1.1.5 Add 200~uL of buffer GB, mix well, and place the micro-centrifuge tube in a thermostat at 70°C for 10min.
1.2 DNA Dilution.
1.2.1 Measure the DNA concentration using a NanoDrop microspectrophotometer.
1.2.2 Calculate concentration by diluting 50~ng/uL with ddH2O and store in the refrigerator at -20°C.

system_prompt: As an expert in molecular biology protocols, specializing in the development of nucleic acid amplification and lateral flow assays for viral detection, provide a structured approach to nucleic acid amplification for EBV detection using a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) and lateral flow assay (LFA) system.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To amplify EBV nucleic acids using RPA. Available materials: RPA buffer, primers, DNA template, ddH2O, magnesium acetate. How to optimize the RPA reaction system and assess its sensitivity?
output: 1. Nucleic Acid Amplification.
1.1 RPA-Specific Assay.
1.1.1 Add 29.5~uL of buffer, 2uL each of unlabeled 10uM upstream and downstream primers, 1uL of cellular extracted DNA, and 13~uL of ddH2O to the reaction tube.
1.1.2 Add a 280mmol/L solution of magnesium acetate in a volume of 2.5uL to initiate the reaction.
1.1.3 Uniformly distribute the reaction solution and place it into the PCR instrument at 39°C for 20min.
1.2 Optimization of RPA Reaction System.
1.2.1 Optimize the reaction time and temperature using B95-8 cell DNA as the template.
1.2.2 Time optimization: vary the reaction time at 5, 10, 15, and 20min.
1.2.3 Temperature optimization: vary the reaction temperatures at 35, 37, 39, 41, and 43°C.
1.3 RPA Sensitivity Examination.
1.3.1 Dilute the previously prepared EBV DNA with a ddH2O gradient to 1×10^6, 1×10^5, 1×10^4, 1×10^3, 1×10^2, 1×10^1, 1×10^0 copies/uL.
1.3.2 Use 1~uL of the diluted DNA for ordinary RPA amplification at 39°C for 15~min.

system_prompt: As an expert in molecular biology protocols, specializing in the development of nucleic acid amplification and lateral flow assays for viral detection, provide a structured approach to the lateral flow assay component for EBV detection using a recombinase polymerase amplification (RPA) and lateral flow assay (LFA) system.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To perform a lateral flow assay (LFA) for EBV detection after RPA amplification. Available materials: RPA reaction components, FITC-labeled probes, nfo enzyme, diluent, lateral flow strips. How to set up the RPA-LFA assay and optimize its conditions?
output: 1. Lateral Flow Assay。
1.1 RPA-LFA Specific Assay。
1.1.1 Set up the RPA reaction with a common forward primer, a reverse primer with Biotin labeling, buffer, DNA template, ddH2O, and magnesium acetate。
1.1.2 Add the FITC-labeled probe, nfo enzyme, and nfo enzyme buffer to the reaction product。
1.1.3 Dilute the final amplification product with diluent at a ratio of 1:100 and add 50~uL to the lateral flow strip。
1.2 Optimization of RPA-LFA Reaction Conditions。
1.2.1 Optimize the reaction time and temperature using 50ng/uL B95-8 cellular DNA as the reaction template。
1.2.2 Time optimization: vary the reaction time of the first step at 5, 10, 15, and 20min。
1.2.3 Temperature optimization: vary the reaction temperatures at 35, 37, 39, 41, and 43°C。
1.3 RPA-LFA Sensitivity Examination。
1.3.2 Use 1~uL of each concentration as the template for amplification at 39°C for 15min.

system_prompt: As a Microbiology and Virology expert specializing in microbial conjugation and high-throughput droplet-based methods, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To enhance microbial conjugation efficiency using a droplet microfluidic platform. Available materials: SU-8 2050, PDMS, LB agar plates, selection antibiotics, TSS media, Novec 7500, PicoSurf. How to fabricate the device, prepare cell cultures, conduct conjugation, and evaluate transconjugants?
output: 1. Device Fabrication.
1.1. Option 1: Traditional Photolithography Method.
1.1.1. Spin coat SU-8 2050 onto a silicon wafer at 2100rpm.
1.1.2. Apply the first soft baking step at 65°C for 24h.
1.1.3. Apply the second soft baking step at 95°C for 20min.
1.1.4. Expose the coated Si wafer in the photolithography mask aligner using a mask design.
1.1.5. Apply a post-exposure baking step at 65°C for 40min, then 95°C for 20min.
1.1.6. Remove the unexposed photoresist using EBR-10A.
1.1.7. Apply a coating of tridecafluoro-1,1,2,2-tetrahydrooctyl trichlorosilane for 60min.
1.2. Option 2: Two-Photon Lithography Method.
1.2.1. Silanize the silicon wafer.
1.2.2. Add IP-S photoresist.
1.2.3. Run Nanoscribe.
1.2.4. Develop the structure.
1.2.5. Post-fabrication silanization of microfabricated structures.
2. Generating the ENTRAP Device Using PDMS.
2.1. Mix 22g of PDMS.
2.2. Place the silicon wafer mold into a Petri dish.
2.3. Pour 20g of material over the mold.
2.4. Secure the Si-SU-8 master mold to the Petri dish using Kapton tape.
2.5. Allow PDMS to cure either at room temperature (25°C) overnight or at 65°C for 1-4h.
3. Fabricating the Bottom Surface of the Channels.
3.1. Coat a clean glass slide with a thin layer of PDMS (30um thickness) by spin-coating at 3000rpm for 30s.
3.2. Allow this PDMS to cure under the same conditions as in step 2.5.
4. Bonding the ENTRAP Device to the PDMS-Coated Glass Slide.
4.1. Carefully cut a large rectangle in the PDMS around the channel patterns.
4.2. Place the PDMS rectangle on the PDMS-coated glass slide.
5. Introduce Tubing for the Inlet and Outlets of the Device.
5.1. Use a needle to poke holes in the device where the inlets and outlets are designed.
6. Oxygen Plasma Bonding.
6.1. Place the device in the plasma cleaner and apply a 90s plasma treatment at 150W and 150mTorr.
7. Cell Culture Preparation.
7.1. Streak strains from glycerol stock onto LB agar plates with selection antibiotics.
7.2. Incubate the streaked agar plates overnight (>14h) at 37°C.
7.3. Ensure at least 25mL of LB is available for culturing and dilution.
7.4. Pick a single large colony and suspend it in 3mL of LB liquid media with selection antibiotics.
7.5. Culture the donor and recipient strain to an OD600 between 0.8 and 1.2.
7.6. Subculture these strains into fresh media with the same selection antibiotics (3-5mL).
7.7. Allow the donor strain to grow to an OD600 of 0.2 and add xylose to a final concentration of 1%.
7.8. Culture both strains to an OD600 between 0.8 and 1.0.
7.9. Pellet cultures by centrifugation at 3000×g for 3min.
7.10. Wash pellets with 1mL of PBS and re-centrifuge at 3000×g for 3min. Repeat twice.
7.11. Resuspend both pellets in TSS media or LB media supplemented with D-alanine (100µg/mL) to a final OD600 of 0.6.
8. Conjugation of Cells in the ENTRAP Device.
8.1. Bake the fully fabricated PDMS DNA ENTRAP microdevices at 80°C for 4h.
8.2. Combine the donor cells with recipient cells at a 1:1 ratio.
8.3. Load at least 500uL of the donor/recipient cell mix into a 1mL BD plastic syringe.
8.4. Prepare the oil phase solution according to Recipe 2. Filter the solution through a 0.2um filter.
8.5. Prime all microfluidic channels and devices with the oil phase solution.
8.6. Load 5mL of the carrier oil/surfactant mixture into a 5mL BD plastic syringe.
8.7. Place the loaded syringes into separate Chemyx Fusion 200 pumps.
8.8. Run both syringe pumps to begin droplet formation.
8.9. Perform imaging under an inverted optical microscope while droplets are being formed.
8.10. Stop the syringe pumps when the desired volume or droplet number is achieved.
8.11. Incubate droplets for at least 1h at ambient temperatures or 37°C.
8.12. Flow the droplets out from the micro-vessel chip.
8.13. Pipette 50uL of the droplets in oil suspension onto a selection agar plate.
9. Transconjugant Selection and Evaluation.
9.1. Inspect the transconjugant plates (10µg/mL tetracycline) for colonies after incubation.
9.2. Pick several colonies and inoculate 3mL cultures with 10µg/mL tetracycline.
9.3. Induce cells with 1mM IPTG when grown to an OD600 of 0.2, then shake for 1h at 37°C.
9.4. Perform various analyses to confirm successful conjugation of DNA.
9.4.1. Option 1: Flow cytometry.
9.4.2. Option 2: Plate reader for fluorescence measurement.
9.4.3. Option 3: Fluorescence microscopy.
9.4.4. Option 4: Colony PCR.
9.4.5. Option 5: Whole-genome sequencing.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology and Culture expert specializing in adipose tissue grafting and fibrous slurry preparation, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To improve cell survival and engraftment in adipose tissue grafting. Available materials: PLGA (82:18 lactide to glycolide), hexafluoroisopropanol, mini mill, 60-mesh sieve, 40-mesh sieve, 20-mesh sieve, adipose tissue, 3mL syringe, 4mm cannula. How to fabricate pulverized PLGA fibers, prepare co-injectable nanofiber and adipose tissue, and perform in vivo fat engraftment surgery?
output: 1. Pulverized Electrospun PLGA Fiber Fabrication.
1.1. Dissolve PLGA at a ratio of 82:18 lactide to glycolide in hexafluoroisopropanol at 6% w/w.
1.2. Mix at room temperature for at least 24h.
1.3. Electrospinning.

1.3.1. Electrospin the polymer solution at +12 kV/.3 kV at a flow rate of 5~mL/h until reaching a 0.1–0.3 mm thick nanofiber sheet at room temperature and humidity with a tip-to-collector distance of 20cm using an 18-gauge needle.
1.3.2. Evaporate the solvent from the nanofiber sheet for 16 h at room temperature.
1.4. Pulverization.
1.4.1. Cut the electrospun mat into 1~cm wide strips and feed into the mini mill.

1.4.2. Perform milling with the 60-mesh sieve for the first pass, then re-run the fibers that passed through that sieve through the 40-mesh sieve mill, and finally run the fibers that passed through that sieve through the 20-mesh sieve to achieve the final desired particle size.
2. Co-injectable Nanofiber and Adipose Tissue Preparation.
2.1. Transport the adipose tissue on ice and place it in appropriate containers.
2.2. Centrifuge at 195× g for 1 min at 4°C to separate the tissue from oils and anesthetics.
2.3. Discard excess oils and debris.
2.4. Combining Fibers and Adipose Tissue.
2.4.1. Place 50mg of fibers into a 2~mL tube.
2.4.2. Add 1~mL of tissue to the fiber-containing tube.
2.4.3. Mix tissue and fibers into a 3mL syringe and cover the end with parafilm for surgical use.
3. Fat Engraftment Surgery Preparation.
3.1. Sterilize all surgical tools, surgical trays, and materials before surgery.
3.2. Set and maintain the surgical warming pads at 37°C during surgery.
3.3. Place mouse cages onto a slide warmer set to 37 ^°C.
3.4. Weigh each mouse and record baseline weights.
3.5. Completely remove hair from the incision area 24h prior to surgery.
4. In Vivo Fat Engraftment Surgery.
4.1. Place the mouse into the induction chamber and anesthetize using 5% isoflurane in room air at 500mL/min.
4.2. Move the mouse to the nose cone on the warming pad and maintain anesthesia at 1.5%-2% isoflurane at 250mL/min.
4.3. Surgical Procedure.
4.3.1. Apply artificial tear ointment to the mouse’s eyes and betadine followed by isopropyl to the incision area.
4.3.2. Create a 1-inch incision horizontally on the upper and lower dorsal area.
4.3.3. Form a cavity under the mouse’s skin by detaching the surrounding fascia using tenotomy scissors.
4.3.4. Push approximately 100-120~uL of warm saline into each side of the incision.
4.4. Injecting Adipose Tissue and Fibers.
4.4.1. Connect a 3mL syringe loaded with adipose tissue and fibers to a 4:mm cannula.
4.4.2. Push 1~mL from the syringe load into the cavity.
4.5. Wound Closure and Post-Surgery Care.
4.5.1. Close the cavity by suturing the skin with 6–0 braided sutures.
4.5.2. Clean the skin of the mouse using an alcohol pad and seal the incision line using liquid glue/bandage.
4.5.3. Remove the mouse from the nose cone, weigh the mouse, and record post-surgery weight.
4.5.4. Place the mouse into a new, clean cage and allow the mouse to recover, monitoring its status until fully awake.

system_prompt: As a Genomics Technologies expert specializing in RNA-seq protocols for MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma cells, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To accurately measure cell number–normalized differential gene expression in MYCN-amplified neuroblastoma cells treated with retinoic acid. Available materials: BE2C cells, RPMI medium, ATRA, DMSO, TRIzol, chloroform, isopropanol, RNeasy extraction columns, DNase, ERCC spike-in mix. How to prepare cells, extract RNA, and perform library preparation and sequencing?
output: 1. Cell Preparation.
1.1. Seeding and Maintenance.
1.1.1. Seed 0.1×10^6 BE2C cells in 6-well plates.
1.1.2. Maintain cells at 37°C.
1.2. Treatment and Growth.
1.2.1. Treat BE2C cells with 5uL of DMSO or 5uM ATRA.
1.2.2. Change 3mL of RPMI with DMSO or 5uM ATRA every 3 days.
1.2.3. Grow cells for six days.
1.3. Cell Collection and Counting.
1.3.1. Aspirate RPMI, wash 1× with 3mL of PBS, and add 1mL of trypsin.
1.3.2. Collect cells, spin down at 800×g for 5 min.
1.3.3. Discard supernatant and wash cells one time with 5mL of PBS.
1.3.4. Resuspend cells in 1mL of PBS.
1.3.5. Combine 20uL of resuspended cells with 20uL of 0.4% trypan blue and mix well.
1.3.6. Pipette 10uL of mix into a Countess chamber slide and insert into Countess 3 automated cell counter.
1.3.7. Document viable cell count per milliliter and calculate absolute viable cell count.
1.4. Cell Pellet and Storage.
1.4.1. Pellet cells, remove supernatant, and snap freeze in dry ice with ethanol.
1.4.2. Store samples at -80°C until ready to proceed.
2. RNA Extraction Test Run.
2.1. Sample Preparation.
2.1.1. Begin with extra fourth sample collected for each experimental group.
2.1.2. Resuspend frozen cell pellets in 1mL of TRIzol reagent and incubate at room temperature for 5 min.
2.2. RNA Extraction.
2.2.1. Add 0.2mL of chloroform, mix for 15s, and incubate for 2 min at room temperature.
2.2.2. Centrifuge samples at 12,000×g for 10 min at 4°C.
2.2.3. Transfer aqueous phase to new tubes and precipitate RNA by adding 0.5mL of isopropanol.
2.2.4. Incubate at room temperature for 10 min and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 10 min at 4°C.
2.2.5. Remove supernatant, wash RNA pellet once with 1.0mL of 75% ethanol, and mix by pipetting up and down.
2.3. RNA Purification.
2.3.1. Dissolve RNA pellet in 100uL of RNase-free water, add 350uL of lysis buffer RLT, and mix.
2.3.2. Add 250uL of ethanol and mix.
2.3.3. Apply sample to RNeasy extraction column and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 1 min at room temperature.
2.3.4. Prepare DNase by adding 10uL of DNase to 70uL of RDD buffer and keep on ice.
2.3.5. Add 350uL of wash buffer 1 RW1, spin at 12,000×g for 15s, and discard flowthrough.
2.3.6. Add 80uL of DNase mix and incubate at room temperature for 15 min.
2.3.7. Add 350uL of wash buffer 1 RW1, spin at 12,000×g for 15s, and discard flowthrough.
2.3.8. Add 500uL of wash buffer 2 RPE, centrifuge at 12,000×g for 15s at room temperature.
2.3.9. Add another 500uL of wash buffer 2 RPE, centrifuge at 12,000×g for 2 min at room temperature.
2.3.10. Transfer column to new 1.5mL collection tube, add 30uL RNase-free water, and centrifuge at 12,000×g for 1 min to elute total RNA.
2.4. RNA Quantification.
2.4.1. Quantify and record total RNA amount in each sample using Nanodrop.
3. RNA Extraction and ERCC Spike-in.
3.1. ERCC Spike-in Preparation.
3.1.1. Calculate volume of ERCC spike-in mix 1 to add based on sample with highest RNA amount.
3.1.2. Serial dilute ERCC spike-in mix 1 according to Table 1.
3.1.3. Determine volume of diluted ERCC spike-in mix 1 to add to sample with highest RNA amount according to Table 2.
3.2. RNA Extraction with ERCC Spike-in.
3.2.1. Resuspend experimental frozen cell pellets in 1mL of TRIzol reagent and incubate at room temperature for 5 min.
3.2.2. Add calculated volume of appropriately diluted ERCC spike-in mix 1 to each sample.
3.2.3. Extract and quantify RNA from each sample by repeating steps B2–18.
4. Library Preparation and Sequencing.
4.1. Library Preparation.
4.1.1. Prepare samples using commercially available library preparation kits, starting with 500ng of purified total RNA.
4.1.2. Quantify finished dsDNA libraries by Qubit fluorometer, TapeStation 4200, and RT-qPCR using Kapa Biosystems library quantification kit.
4.2. Sequencing.
4.2.1. Pool indexed libraries in equimolar ratios and pair-end sequence on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 sequencer with NovaSeq 6000 Reagent Kit v1.5, 100 cycles at 0.7nM loading concentration.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology & Culture expert specializing in coculture systems for parasympathetic neurons, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To study parasympathetic neuron innervation in salivary gland functionality using a novel coculture model integrating human parasymNs with mouse von Ebner’s gland cells. Available materials: Sox10-Cre::RFP mice, Geltrex, Accutase, stem cell banker, DMEM/F12, DPBS, trypsin-EDTA. How to perform salivary gland dissection, cell dissociation, cryobanking, and parasymN coculture?
output: 1. Salivary Gland Dissection.
1.1 Euthanize 8-week-old Sox10-Cre::RFP mice in CO2 chamber and confirm death via cervical dislocation.
1.2 Place mouse in surgical area, wet head with 70% ethanol, and decapitate.
1.3 Open mouse oral cavity.
1.3.1 Hold head and open mouth by pulling skin over skull and below mandible.
1.3.2 Cut corners of mouth using dissecting scissors.
1.4 Dissect tongue and mandible.
1.4.1 Remove tongue with mandible and skin.
1.4.2 Transfer to 30mL fresh sterile DPBS and wash five times.
1.5 Separate tongue tissue.
1.5.1 Inject 0.5mL tongue tissue separation solution into subepithelial space of posterior tongue.
1.5.2 Incubate for 30 minutes at 37°C.
1.6 Dissect von Ebner’s glands.
1.6.1 Dissect posterior tongue region with RFP+ von Ebner’s glands.
1.6.2 Cut epithelium of circumvallate papilla region and peel off.
1.7 Collect von Ebner’s gland tissue.
1.7.1 Dissect and collect 0.1mL von Ebner’s salivary gland tissue under fluorescent microscope.
1.7.2 Wash glands in 15mL fresh sterile DPBS.
2. Salivary Gland Cell Dissociation.
2.1 Transfer glands to 35mm dish.
2.2 Cut tissues into small pieces using fine-tip scissors.
2.3 Incubate tissue pieces.
2.3.1 Incubate in 3mL salivary gland cell dissociation solution for 30 minutes at 37°C.
2.3.2 Gently agitate tissues every 5 minutes using 1mL pipette tips.
2.4 Stop reaction and centrifuge.
2.4.1 Add 1mL dissociation termination solution.
2.4.2 Centrifuge cell suspension at 450×g for 10 minutes at 4°C and remove supernatant.
2.5 Remove remaining trypsin-EDTA.
2.5.1 Repeat centrifugation to remove trypsin-EDTA.
2.5.2 Filter cells using 70μm then 35μm cell strainer.
3. Salivary Cell Passaging.
3.1 Centrifuge cell suspension at 200×g for 5 minutes.
3.2 Aspirate medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
3.3 Add trypsin-EDTA and incubate for 5 minutes at 37°C.
3.4 Gently pipette 3–5 times to fully dissociate cells.
3.5 Transfer and centrifuge.
3.5.1 Transfer solution to conical tube.
3.5.2 Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend in 1mL salivary gland cell medium.
3.6 Replate cells at 15×10^3/cm^2 density.
3.7 Change medium the next day and every 2–3 days.
4. Salivary Cell Cryo-banking.
4.1 Resuspend 80% confluent cells in 1mL medium with 10% DMSO.
4.2 Transfer to cryogenic tube and freeze at -80°C.
4.3 Move vial to LN tank for long-term storage.
5. NCC Induction.
5.1 Prepare Geltrex-coated plates.
5.1.1 Thaw Geltrex at 4°C overnight.
5.1.2 Dilute with ice-cold DMEM/F12 and coat plates.
5.1.3 Incubate at 4°C overnight.
5.2 Plate hPSCs at 125k cells/cm^2 density.
5.3 Change medium.
5.3.1 Fully change medium with d0, 1 media on day 1.
5.3.2 Fully change medium with D2–10 medium on day 2 and every two days after.
6. Dissociate NCCs for Cryobanking.
6.1 Aspirate medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
6.2 Add Accutase and incubate for 20-30 minutes at 37°C.
6.3 Transfer and centrifuge.
6.3.1 Transfer solution to conical tube.
6.3.2 Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend in ice-cold stem cell banker.
6.4 Freeze cells at -80°C and move to LN tank.
7. Dissociate NCCs for SCP Differentiation.
7.1 Aspirate medium and wash cells twice with PBS.
7.2 Add Accutase and incubate for 20-30 minutes at 37°C.
7.3 Transfer and centrifuge.
7.3.1 Transfer solution to conical tube.
7.3.2 Centrifuge at 200×g for 5 minutes and resuspend in day 10–16 medium.
7.4 Replate cells at 1×10^6/well density.
7.5 Add medium on next day and feed on days 13 and 15.
8. SCP Replating for ParasymN Differentiation/Coculture.
8.1 Collect SCP spheroids in culture medium into conical tube.
8.2 Centrifuge at 200×g for 3 minutes and aspirate supernatant.
8.3 Add Accutase and incubate for 20-30 minutes at 37°C.
8.4 Gently pipette spheroids with P1000 pipette.
8.5 Replate SCP cells at 1×10^5/cm^2 density on top of 80% confluent salivary cells.
8.6 Fully change medium on next day and every 2–3 days after.

system_prompt: As an expert in Neuroscience Methods, specializing in automated rodent behavior assessment using ArUco markers, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step coordination while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To automate rodent engagement assessment in a go/no-go task using ArUco markers. Available materials: OmniTrak system, 3D printer, MATLAB, Python, Visual Studio Code, and behavioral chambers. How to construct, assemble, and operate the automated system?
output: 1. Constructing the Behavioral Chamber.
1.1. Preparing the Sound-Attenuating Chamber.
1.1.1. Adhere acoustic foam wedges to the inside walls of the sound-attenuating chamber using super glue or double-sided foam tape.
1.1.2. Refer to Figure 1A for the intended outcome.
1.2. Setting up the OmniTrak Operant Conditioning Chamber.
1.2.1. Place the OmniTrak operant conditioning chamber inside the sound-attenuating chamber.
1.2.2. Mount the OmniTrak controller board to the chamber's right-side panel using double-sided foam tape.
1.2.3. Connect the RJ45 cable from the nose-poke module to the controller board.
1.2.4. Place the reward pellet dispenser on the chamber's top right edge and connect it to the module using vinyl tubing.
1.2.5. Insert the remaining RJ45 and power connector cables into the dispenser and controller board.
1.2.6. Fill the dispenser reservoir halfway with dustless sugar pellets.
1.2.7. Connect the controller board to the computer using the USB cable.
1.2.8. Power on the OmniTrak system by inserting the power cable into a wall socket.
1.3. 3D Printing Chamber Components.
1.3.1. Download the .stl files from the GitHub repository.
1.3.2. Slice the files in Cura software for your 3D printer.
1.3.3. Print the required files using an FDM printer with PLA filament.
2. Installing Cameras.
2.1. Assemble three 3D-printed camera mounts.
2.2. Mount the behavior camera to the top T-Slot rail closest to the chamber doors and the two ArUco tracking cameras to the top left and right rails.
2.3. Plug each camera’s USB cable into the computer through the chamber’s hole.
3. Creating and Attaching the Tensioner Bar, Commutator, and Tether.
3.1. Modifying the Commutator.
3.1.1. Cut the exposed wires at the top and bottom of the device.
3.1.2. Assign pin numbers to the colored wires at both ends.
3.1.3. Solder the top wires to two rows of eight male breakaway pins.
3.1.4. Solder the bottom wires to two rows of ten female stackable header pins.
3.2. Creating the Tether.
3.2.1. Cut the Omnetics tether adapter to 11.5 inches.
3.2.2. Cut eleven 0.5-inch pieces of 3mm heat shrink tube and slide them over the tether wires.
3.2.3. Cut a 10.5-inch piece of stainless-steel spring cable shielding and slide it over the tether cord.
3.2.4. Solder the wires to two rows of ten male breakaway pins.
3.3. Assembling the Cable Tensioner Bar.
3.3.1. Clip a 1/4-inch binder clip to the center of the top T-slot rail.
3.3.2. Secure the clip with two 6-inch cable ties.
3.3.3. Fasten the hex wrench to the binder clip’s bottom loop with additional cable ties.
3.3.4. Double-wrap three rubber bands around the hex wrench and the clip’s top loop.
4. Connecting the Oscilloscope.
4.1. Place the oscilloscope on top of the chamber.
4.2. Insert its USB cable into the computer.
4.3. Plug in its power supply into a nearby outlet.
5. Connecting the Electrical Stimulator.
5.1. Place the PlexStim device inside the chamber to the right of the conditioning chamber.
5.2. Plug its power supply into a nearby outlet through the chamber’s hole.
5.3. Connect the BNC cables between the stimulator and oscilloscope’s monitor channels.
5.4. Insert the stimulator’s stimulation cable into the commutator.
6. Wiring the ATmega328 Microcontroller.
6.1. Follow the wiring diagram in Figure 4 to connect the microcontroller to the RGB LED strip and pneumatic solenoid.
6.2. Mount the microcontroller to the chamber’s right-side panel with double-sided foam tape.
6.3. Insert the microcontroller’s USB type-B cable into the computer.
7. Mounting the RGB LED Strip.
7.1. Gather the 3D-printed mounting kit parts.
7.2. Glue the rectangular strips to the inside of the bracket pieces.
7.3. Adhere the bracket pieces to the conditioning chamber’s side panels.
7.4. Thread the RGB LED strip through the chamber and bracket mounts.
8. Connecting the Pneumatic Solenoid.
8.1. Insert one end of the vinyl tubing into the regulator on a medical-grade air tank.
8.2. Cut the tubing 4 feet from the opposite end and set aside.
8.3. Attach the cut end to the “IN” hole on the solenoid with brass fittings.
8.4. Connect the severed tubing piece to the “OUT” hole on the solenoid.
9. Installing and Configuring Software Packages.
9.1. Behavioral Task MATLAB Code.
9.1.1. Download the entire repository from the provided GitHub page.
9.1.2. Extract the downloaded zip file.
9.1.3. Open the Excel file AnimalWeightCheck.xlsx and replace the animal names and weights.
9.2. MATLAB.
9.2.1. Download MATLAB vR2023b from MathWorks’ website.
9.2.2. Install MATLAB and set its active file directory to the ArucoDetection → MATLAB Behavior Program file path.
9.2.3. Install the required packages from the Add-Ons menu.
9.3. PlexStim for Electrical Stimulator.
9.3.1. Download PlexStim v2.3 from Plexon Inc.’s website.
9.3.2. Install the software by following the on-screen instructions.
9.4. TekVisa for Oscilloscope.
9.4.1. Download TekVisa v4.0.4 from Tektronix’ website.
9.4.2. Install the software by following the on-screen instructions.
9.5. Python.
9.5.1. Download Python v3.10.11 from Python’s website.
9.5.2. Install Python by following the prompted instructions.
9.6. Visual Studio Code and ArUco Marker Tracking Code.
9.6.1. Download Visual Studio Code from its official website.
9.6.2. Install the application by following the prompted instructions.
9.6.3. Open Visual Studio Code and install the required extensions.
10. ArUco Marker Mounting Hardware.
10.1. Assembling the Hardware.
10.1.1. Follow the instructions in step A3 to print the required hardware pieces.
10.1.2. Locate one 1/4-inch generic binder clip and carefully remove each of the two metal loops from the clip.
10.1.3. Open the image of the ArUco marker into any image processing application and print the marker on white stock printer paper.
10.2. Securing the I-Bracket to the Animal.
10.2.1. While the animal is anesthetized, permanently glue the I-Bracket around the exposed microelectrode array 16-channel Omnetics connector port.
10.2.2. Apply sparing amounts of super glue around each side of the Omnetics connector before slotting on the I-Bracket.
11. Running the Behavioral Task and ArUco Tracking Code.
11.1. Opening the Code.
11.1.1. Power on the electrical stimulator and the oscilloscope.
11.1.2. Open the BehaviorApp.mlapp file from MATLAB and the AnimalDetect.py file from Visual Studio Code.
11.2. Calibrating the Cameras.
11.2.1. Check to make sure that the cameras are properly oriented.
11.2.2. Place the ArUco marker mounting piece inside the operant conditioning chamber in different positions to test whether the marker is being properly tracked.
12. Locating Post-Session Results.
12.1. Behavioral Performance Data.
12.1.1. After a behavioral session has concluded, locate the Excel file containing the raw behavioral data for each individual trial.
12.1.2. Open the specific Excel session file just produced.
12.2. Stimulation Waveform Data.
12.2.1. Navigate to the ArucoDetection → MATLAB Behavior Program → StimDataOutput folder.
12.2.2. Open the folder specific to a behavioral session that was run.
13. Verification of ArUco Tracking Setup.
13.1. Once the behavioral chamber is fully operational, evaluate the performance of the ArUco tracking setup.
13.2. Manually score each trial of a behavioral session, marking whether the animal was “engaged” or “distracted”.
13.3. Open the corresponding Excel session file and review the Distraction Annotation column in Sheet 2.

system_prompt: As an expert in molecular biology techniques, specializing in gene-editing protocols for human pluripotent stem cells, design a hierarchical step decomposition with parameter inheritance, cross-step reagent coordination, and exclusion of theoretical explanations.
instruction: Structure the protocol into multi-level operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To efficiently generate gene-edited human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs) with high homology-directed repair (HDR) rates through simplified assembly of adeno-associated viral (AAV) donor templates. Available materials: Cas9 ribonucleoprotein, AAV donor templates, Golden Gate cloning reagents, AAV-293 cells, mTeSR Plus medium, and nucleofection system. How to design gRNAs, assemble targeting vectors, isolate AAV virions, and transduce hPSCs?
output: 1. Design Strategy and Selection of Target gRNA.
1.1. Design gRNAs for the desired target site using the CHOPCHOP design tool.
1.2. Select a gRNA target site that will be disrupted by recombination with the targeting vector, preferably by disrupting its protospacer adjacent motif (PAM).
1.3. Choose 1-2 gRNAs per site based on their mismatch number and efficiency score, preferably selecting guides with efficiency scores >45 and no off-target sites with <3 mismatches.
2. Design of Targeting Vector and Generation of Fragments by PCR or Custom Synthesis.
2.1. Design the targeting vector by generating a desired target sequence flanked by 300-500 bp homology arms.
2.2. Fragment Generation.
2.2.1. Amplify homology arms by PCR with BbsI-compatible primer extensions using a high-fidelity polymerase.
2.2.2. Alternatively, order homology arms and/or the edited sequence as synthetic fragments.
2.3. Gel-purify fragments amplified by PCR and assess quality and concentration using UV spectroscopy.
3. One-Step Assembly of Targeting Vector by Golden Gate Assembly into Universal AAV Vector.
3.1. Set up the Golden Gate assembly reaction in a PCR tube following the recipe in Table 3.
3.2. Perform the Golden Gate reaction in a thermal cycler using the program in Table 4.
3.3. Transform competent bacteria with the Golden Gate reaction and plate transformed bacterial culture into LB-agar plates with ampicillin.
3.4. Pick 4-6 colonies and grow in LB with ampicillin overnight, expecting at least one positive colony.
3.5. Miniprep cultures and test for correct assembly using diagnostic restriction enzyme digests.
3.6. Amplify a correct clone by growing a 35 mL LB culture and purify the plasmid using the Plasmid Plus Midi Kit.
4. Rapid Isolation of AAV Virions from AAV-293 Cell Conditioned Media.
4.1. Culture AAV-293 cells in DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS.
4.2. Co-transfect the AAV-293 cells with the AAV targeting vector along with pHelper and RC-DJ plasmids using the Cal-Phos method.
4.3. Collect the media 72 hours post-transfection and clear dead cells and debris by centrifugation.
4.4. Concentrate the virus solution to 500 µL using an Amicon Ultra-4 centrifugal filter and wash with mTeSR Plus medium.
4.5. Concentrate the virus solution to a final volume of 250 µL of cleaned mTeSR Plus media containing virion particles.
5. Nucleofection of hPSCs with CRISPR-RNPs and Subsequent Transduction of Cells with AAV Carrying the Targeting Vector.
5.1. Culture hPSCs for one week prior to performing nucleofection and maintain cells in mTeSR Plus medium on Matrigel-coated plastic.
5.2. CRISPR-RNP Preparation.
5.2.1. Anneal Alt-R crRNA with Alt-R tracr-RNA in a 1:1 ratio at 50 µM final concentration of each gRNA.
5.2.2. Prepare Cas9 RNPs by mixing recombinant Alt-R S.p. HiFi Cas9 Nuclease V3 with the annealed crRNA and tracr-RNA.
5.3. Nucleofection of hPSCs.
5.3.1. Treat cells with ROCK inhibitor for 2 hours prior to transfection.
5.3.2. Detach cells with Accutase and count cells using an automated cell counter or Burker chamber.
5.3.3. Nucleofect cells using a 4D-Nucleofector system with the RNP complex.
5.4. Add AAV particles to the media within 10 minutes after nucleofection and culture cells for 24-72 hours prior to analysis.
5.5. Change media to mTeSR Plus without ROCK inhibitor 24 hours after transfection and monitor cell viability.
6. Optional: Isolation of Single Clones by FACS for Expansion and PCR Screening.
6.1. Prepare a 96-well plate coated with Matrigel for 1 hour at 37°C.
6.2. Detach cells with Accutase and resuspend in mTeSR Plus supplemented with CloneR2.
6.3. Configure gates and flow of an automated cell sorter to sort single viable cells into 96-well plates.
6.4. Replace media with mTeSR Plus for clonal expansion 48 hours post-sorting and change media every other day.
6.5. Expand clones into two duplicate 24-well plates for analysis and banking.

system_prompt: As a Zebrafish Genetics and Maternal Mutant Expert, specialize in oocyte-specific knockout systems and maternal gene function studies. Apply multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and reagent/instrument coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/instrument continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To overcome the challenges of studying maternal gene functions in zebrafish caused by zygotic lethality, this protocol introduces a rapid and efficient oocyte-specific knockout system. Available materials include CRISPRscan software, AxyPrep PCR Clean-Up Kit, NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer, TURBO DNase, phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol, chloroform, isopropanol, agarose, GFP-positive embryos. How to construct sgRNA expression plasmids, perform in vitro transcription, and generate maternal mutants?
output: 1. Construction of sgRNA Expression Plasmid.
1.1 Prediction of sgRNA Targeting Sites.
1.1.1 Predict at least six different sgRNA targeting sites using the online CRISPRscan software.
1.1.2 Select sgRNAs with high CRISPRscan score and low CFD score.
1.1.3 Avoid overlaps of selected sgRNA-targeting sites and select sites close to the start codon ATG.
1.2 Amplification and Purification of Each sgRNA DNA Template.
1.2.1 Prepare the Fill-in PCR mixture on ice.
1.2.2 Run the PCR program as shown in Table 2.
1.2.3 Purify the PCR products with the AxyPrep PCR Clean-Up Kit.
1.2.4 Measure the concentration of the purified DNA template using a NanoDrop 2000 spectrophotometer.
1.3 In Vitro Transcription of sgRNA.
1.3.1 Thaw frozen reagents and mix thoroughly.
1.3.2 Set up the in vitro transcription reaction mixture on ice.
1.3.3 Incubate at 37°C for 2h.
1.3.4 Remove the DNA template by adding TURBO DNase.
1.4 sgRNA Purification and Precipitation.
1.4.1 Add 70μL of RNase-free H2O and mix thoroughly.
1.4.2 Add an equal volume of phenol:chloroform:isoamyl alcohol and vortex.
1.4.3 Add an equal volume of chloroform and vortex.
1.4.4 Add an equal volume of isopropanol and mix well.
1.5 Test sgRNA Efficiency.
1.5.1 Dilute Cas9 protein to 200ng/μL.
1.5.2 Mix 1μL of sgRNA with 1μL of Cas9 protein.
1.5.3 Inject 2nL mixture into each 1-cell stage embryo.
1.5.4 Collect embryos and extract DNA for PCR amplification.
2. Construction of Separate sgRNA Expression Plasmids.
2.1 Synthesis of sgRNA Annealing Primer.
2.1.1 Synthesize sgRNA annealing primer through a commercial company.
2.1.2 Anneal the primers using a thermocycler.
2.2 Ligation to U6 Vectors.
2.2.1 Ligate sgRNA oligos to corresponding U6 vectors.
2.2.2 Transform the ligation mixture into DH50 competent cells.
2.2.3 Perform colony PCR to identify positive colonies.
2.3 Construction of pGGDestISceIEG-XsgRNA Vector.
2.3.1 Set up the Golden Gate reaction mixture.
2.3.2 Perform Golden Gate assembly using a thermocycler.
2.3.3 Transform the mixture into DH50 competent cells.
2.3.4 Perform colony PCR to identify positive colonies.
3. Transgenesis of sgRNA Expression Vector.
3.1 Assembly of Injection Solution.
3.1.1 Assemble the injection solution on ice.
3.1.2 Inject 2nL of solution into 1-cell stage embryos.
3.2 Test I-Sce I Activity.
3.2.1 Incubate the rest of the injection solution at 37°C for 30min.
3.2.2 Subject the solution to electrophoresis to check I-Sce I efficiency.
4. Pre-screening of Founders.
4.1 Synthesis of bmp2b sgRNA.
4.1.1 Synthesize bmp2b sgRNA as described above.
4.1.2 Inject bmp2b sgRNA into embryos of founder fish.
4.2 Observation of Embryos.
4.2.1 Observe embryos at 12hpf.
4.2.2 Quantify the dorsalized embryos.
5. Aspiration of Blastoderm Cells for Genotyping.
5.1 Preparation of Agarose Plate.
5.1.1 Add 1.5% agarose in water and boil to melt.
5.1.2 Pour the molten agarose into a 90mm Petri dish.
5.2 Preparation of Needles.
5.2.1 Pull glass capillaries to make tip-closed needles.
5.2.2 Cut the capillary tips to achieve an opening diameter of 30-40μm.
5.3 Aspiration of Cells.
5.3.1 Mate putative founder with wild-type fish and collect embryos.
5.3.2 Pick up GFP-positive embryos at 1-cell stage.
5.3.3 Aspirate 20-40 cells from the embryo.
6. Phenotype Analysis of Embryos.
6.1 Live Imaging.
6.1.1 Observe embryos at desired stage.
6.1.2 Recognize maternal mutants by live imaging.
6.2 Whole-Mount In Situ Hybridization.
6.2.1 Fix embryos with 4% PFA at 4°C overnight.
6.2.2 Wash samples with PBST and subject to whole-mount in situ hybridization.
7. Genotyping of Maternal Mutants.
7.1 Extraction of Total RNA.
7.1.1 Add 60μL of chloroform and vortex for 5-10s.
7.1.2 Centrifuge at 12,000×g for 15min at 4°C.
7.2 Reverse Transcription.
7.2.1 Reverse-transcribe the cDNA following the cDNA synthesis kit manual.
7.2.2 Use the cDNA as the template to amplify the coding sequence of the target gene.

system_prompt: As a Molecular Biology Techniques expert specializing in metabolic RNA labeling and translational ribosome affinity purification (P-TRAP), demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To measure nascent mRNA synthesis and translation by integrating 4-thiouridine metabolic labeling with translational ribosome affinity purification (P-TRAP). Available materials: HEK293 cells, DMEM medium, 4sU labeling mix, Dynabeads Protein G beads, antibodies. How to perform P-TRAP, metabolic labeling, RNA purification, and sequencing?
output: 1. Cell Seeding and Incubation.

1.1 Seed 2×10^5 HEK293 cells in 2 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin into a 6-well plate and incubate overnight in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2 at 37°C.
1.2 Use one well per sample.
2. Lysis and Centrifugation.
2.1 Aspirate the medium from the plate and add 250 μL of freshly prepared ice-cold 1% Triton X100 lysis buffer.
2.2 Gently shake the 6-well plate to ensure that the lysis buffer covers the entire surface of each well, transfer to a 1.5 mL tube using a micropipette, and centrifuge at 20,000×g for 10 min at 4°C.
3. Supernatant Collection and Input Fraction Preparation.
3.1 Collect the supernatant in a 1.5 mL tube.
3.2 Keep 10 μL of the supernatant in another 1.5 mL tube as input fraction for western blotting.
4. Antibody Solution Preparation and Immunoprecipitation.
4.1 Prepare the 10× antibody solution with RNase A.
4.2 Add 20 μL of 10× antibody solution with RNase A to 180 μL of the supernatant in a new 1.5 mL tube and rotate at 4°C for 60 min.
5. Dynabeads Preparation and Washing.
5.1 Dispense 7 μL of DynabeadsTM Protein G beads per sample into a new 1.5 mL tube and wash the beads by 200 μL with wash buffer.
5.2 Transfer 200 μL of sample solution to the Dynabeads tube and rotate at 4°C for 40 min.
6. Unbound Fraction Preparation and Beads Washing.
6.1 Place the tube in a magnetic rack and remove the clear supernatant.
6.2 Keep 10 μL of the supernatant in another 1.5 mL tube as an unbound fraction for western blotting.
7. Elution and Eluted Fraction Preparation.
7.1 Wash the beads three times with 1 mL of wash buffer.
7.2 Add 30 μL of SDS buffer to the beads and resuspend to elute the immunoprecipitants.
8. Western Blotting.
8.1 Place the e-PAGEL 5%-20% precast gel in the WSE-1165W mini slab filled with Tris-Glycine SDS running buffer.
8.2 Load 1.5 μL of molecular weight marker and 5 μL of each sample prepared in Section A.
8.3 Activate the PVDF membrane by soaking it in EtOH for a few seconds.
8.4 Transfer proteins from the gel to PVDF membranes under wet transfer conditions.
8.5 Block the membrane with 10 mL of 1% BSA/TBST.
8.6 Prepare each of the primary antibody mix and incubate at 4°C with rotation overnight.
8.7 Wash the membranes three times with 10 mL of TBST.
8.8 Prepare each of the secondary antibody mix and incubate at RT for at least 30 min with rotation.
8.9 Wash the membranes three times with 10 mL of TBST.
8.10 Incubate the membranes with the appropriate HRP western blot substrate solution and acquire images.
9. 4sU Metabolic RNA Labeling and Extraction of Cytosolic RNA and Ribosome-Bound RNA.
9.1 Seed 1×10^6 HEK293 cells in 10 mL of DMEM supplemented with 10% FBS, 100 U/mL penicillin, and 100 μg/mL streptomycin into a 10 cm dish.
9.2 Incubate overnight in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2 at 37°C.
9.3 Add labeling solution to the cultured medium and incubate for 3 h.
9.4 Aspirate the medium from the plate and add 1 mL of freshly prepared ice-cold 1% Triton X-100 lysis buffer.
9.5 Gently shake the 10 cm dish by hand to ensure that the lysis buffer covers the entire surface of each well.
9.6 Collect the supernatant in a 1.5 mL tube.
9.7 Prepare the 10× antibody mix with RNasin.
9.8 Transfer 200 μL of the supernatant in a new 1.5 mL tube and add 500 μL of ISOGEN II supplemented with 1 mM DTT.
9.9 Transfer 450 μL of the supernatants in a new 1.5 mL tube and add 50 μL of 10× antibody mix with RNasin.
9.10 Dispense 28 μL of DynabeadsTM Protein G beads per sample into a new 1.5 mL tube and wash the beads with 1 mL of wash buffer.
9.11 Transfer all of the sample solution to the Dynabeads tube and rotate at 4°C for 40 min.
9.12 Place the tube in a magnetic rack, remove the clear supernatant, and wash the beads three times with 1 mL of wash buffer.
9.13 Add 500 μL of ISOGEN II supplemented with 1 mM DTT to the beads and resuspend to elute the immunoprecipitants.
10. RNA Purification and Alkylation.
10.1 Incubate the RNA samples at 37°C for 5 min.
10.2 Vortex for 15 s and stand tubes at RT for 10 min.
10.3 Centrifuge at 20,000×g for 10 min at RT with a swing rotor.
10.4 Transfer 500 μL of supernatants to the new 1.5 mL tubes.
10.5 Add 500 μL of 2-propanol supplemented with 1 mM DTT and vortex for 15 s.
10.6 Centrifuge at 20,000×g for 15 min at RT with a swing rotor and discard the supernatants.
10.7 Add 15 μL of nuclease-free water supplemented with 1 mM DTT to the RNA pellet and resuspend.
10.8 Measure RNA concentration by nanodrop.
10.9 Prepare the 4sU alkylation mix.
10.10 Incubate at 50°C for 15 min with the DTU-1CN Dry Thermal Unit.
10.11 Add 1 μL of 1 M DTT, 1 μL of 20 mg/mg glycogen, 5 μL of 3 M NaOAc, and 125 μL of EtOH to each sample.
10.12 Vortex for 15 s and centrifuge at 20,000×g for 30 min at 4°C.
11. Sequencing.
11.1 Prepare the sequencing library using the QuantSeq 3' mRNA-Seq Library Prep Kit FWD for Illumina.
11.2 Use 500 ng of RNA as an input.
11.3 Assess the quantity of the libraries with the QubitTM dsDNA Quantification kit.
11.4 Prepare the required volume of the Qubit working solution.
11.5 Determine the concentration of each library and pool them in an equimolar ratio.
11.6 Sequence samples on Illumina HiSeq system.

system_prompt: As a Bioimaging Technologies expert specializing in mammary gland whole-mount staining and microscopic analysis, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To visualize ductal structures and analyze developmental changes in the mouse mammary gland using whole-mount staining with Carmine Alum. Available materials: Carnoy’s fixative, 70% ethanol, Carmine Alum, xylene, Permount or neutral balsam, dissecting microscope. How to isolate mammary gland tissue, perform whole-mount staining, and analyze the stained tissue?
output: 1. Isolation of Mouse Mammary Gland Tissue.
1.1 Euthanize an 8-week-old female mouse using CO2 inhalation.
1.2 Secure the limbs of the mice to a foam board with pushpins.
1.3 Skin Incision and Exposure of Mammary Glands.
1.3.1 Make a skin incision on the abdomen and extend it toward the midline and hind limbs without breaching the peritoneum.
1.3.2 Securely pin the opened skin flat onto the foam board to adequately expose the fourth pair of mammary glands.
1.4 Removal and Preparation of Mammary Gland Tissue.
1.4.1 Gently grasp the distal end of the entire fat pads using sterile forceps and slowly remove the mammary glands from the skin using sterile scissors.
1.4.2 Transfer the entire tissue onto a glass slide and gently spread the tissue using forceps.
1.4.3 Place the glass slide at room temperature and allow the tissue edges to dry.
1.5 Transfer the tissue into a 50mL centrifuge tube for subsequent whole-mount staining.
2. Whole-Mount Staining.
2.1 Fixation.
2.1.1 Slowly add newly prepared Carnoy’s fixative to a 50mL centrifuge tube, ensuring complete immersion of the entire mammary gland tissue.
2.2 Washing and Storage.
2.2.1 Transfer the glass slides to a 50mL centrifuge tube for washing with 70% ethanol.
2.2.2 Pass the glass slides sequentially through 50% and 30% ethanol and ddH2O.
2.3 Staining.
2.3.1 Transfer the glass slides to Carmine Alum and adjust staining duration based on the size and thickness of mammary gland tissue.
2.3.2 Wash the glass slides with wash buffer until the solution becomes clear.
2.4 Clearing and Mounting.
2.4.1 Pass the glass slides sequentially through 70%, 95%, and 100% ethanol.
2.4.2 Transfer glass slides to xylene for tissue clearing.
2.4.3 Apply Permount or neutral balsam to cover the entire mammary gland tissue.
3. Whole-Mount Analysis.
3.1 Capture images of the stained entire mammary gland tissue using a dissecting microscope.
3.2 Counting of TEBs and Bifurcated TEBs.
3.2.1 Count the number of TEBs directly on the images.
3.2.2 Count the number of bifurcated TEBs directly on the images.
3.3 Counting of Ducts and Acini.
3.3.1 Count the number of ducts at distances of 5, 10, and 15mm from the lymph node.
3.3.2 Count the number of acini at distances of 5, 10, and 15mm from the lymph node.

system_prompt: As a Bioimaging Technologies expert specializing in fluorescence lifetime imaging and protein aggregation studies, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To study protein aggregation in CHO HT-aggrER cells with sub-organellar resolution using Fast 3D FLIM combined with P1 fluorophore and HaloTag ligand. Available materials: complete nutrient mixture F12, Trypsin-EDTA, P1 solvatochromic fluorophore, Janelia Fluor 646 HaloTag ligand. How to prepare cells, perform pulse labeling, and conduct FLIM imaging?
output: 1. Preparation of CHO HT-aggrER cells for 3D-FLIM imaging.
1.1 Grow cells in complete nutrient mixture F12 media in a cell culture incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2 until cells reach 70%-80% confluency in a 10cm dish.
1.2 Aspirate complete nutrient mixture F12 from cells, wash once with 1× DPBS, add 1mL of Trypsin-EDTA, and return cells to incubator for 3 min.
1.3 Once detached, add 3~mL of complete nutrient mixture F12 media to cells and pipette up and down 10 times to make a single-cell suspension.
1.4 Count cells using a hemacytometer or automated cell counter.
1.5 Transfer cells to a 15mL falcon tube and centrifuge at 200×g for 5min.
1.6 Aspirate supernatant and resuspend cells with complete media at 1×10^6 cells/mL.
1.7 Seed cells at 3,000 cells/cm^2 in a coverslip glass-bottomed cell culture vessel.
1.8 Return to incubator and grow to 70% confluency.
2. Pulse labeling of HT-aggrER with P1 solvatochromic fluorophore.
2.1 Dilute P1 stock to 4~uM final concentration in prewarmed complete nutrient mixture F12 media.
2.2 Take cells grown from Section A and replace media with P1 staining solution.
2.3 Return cells to the incubator for 45min.
2.4 Remove P1 staining solution and wash with prewarmed complete media.
2.5 Replace with prewarmed complete nutrient mixture F12 media.
2.6 Now that HT-agg^ER has been pulse-labeled, the cells can be subjected to a treatment of choice prior to imaging to observe the effect of the treatment on protein aggregates over time.
3. Counter-labeling with 646 HaloTag ligand to visualize ER.
3.1 Directly before imaging, newly synthesized HT-aggrER can be pulse-labeled with Janelia Fluor 646 HaloTag ligand.
3.2 Stain cells with Janelia Fluor 646 HaloTag staining solution for 45min prior to imaging.
3.3 Remove Janelia Fluor 646 HaloTag staining solution and wash twice with prewarmed 1× DPBS.
3.4 Add 500uL of fresh complete nutrient mixture F12 media to the well and subject to imaging.
4. FLIM live cell imaging of P1-label.
4.1 Warm the microscope stage to 37°C and set CO2 level to 5%.
4.2 Place the cell sample on the microscope stage.
4.3 Locate and focus on cells through eyepieces using brightfield illumination to minimize bleaching of P1 fluorophore.
4.4 Set microscope parameters in LAS X software.
4.4.1 FLIM mode.
4.4.2 Laser 1: Excitation/emission 440/450-500 nm, pulsed laser.
4.4.3 Laser 2: Excitation/emission 646/655-750nm.
4.4.4 HyDx detector in counting mode.
4.4.5 Frame size 512×512 pixels.
4.4.6 Scan speed 400Hz.
4.4.7 Count frame average of 15–20.
4.4.8 Set Z-stack for the cell (begin and end).
4.5 Start image acquisition (Start Experiment button).
5. Confocal live imaging in the LIGHTNING mode of 646 HaloTag ligand.
5.1 Immediately after FLIM imaging of cells, deselect FLIM mode and select LIGHTNING mode of LAS X software.
5.2 Do not change the Z-stack or frame-size settings acquired in FLIM mode.
5.3 Start image acquisition (Start experiment button).
6. Image rendering.
6.1 Raw FLIM image rendering.
6.1.1 Select FLIM mode.
6.1.2 Set the lifetime range (2.5–6 ns).
6.1.3 Export image in TIFF or PNG format.
6.1.4 Export in the format of 3D-movie.
6.2 Aggregate size analysis of FLIM data in Icy Software.
6.2.1 Open the exported TIFF or PNG FLIM image files in Icy Software.
6.2.2 Select Build RGB Image.
6.2.3 Deselect Ch1 and Ch2 (green and blue) channels to leave only red pixels, reflecting regions of fluorescence lifetime >4.5 ns.
6.2.4 Open the Aggregates Detector protocol.
6.2.5 Adjust the Threshold and Min volume settings to identify aggregates of the desired intensity and size.
6.2.6 Run Aggregates Detector and then navigate to the R OI tab on the right-hand side of the viewer.
6.3 3D FLIM image rendering.
6.3.1 Select 3D tool on LASX software.
6.3.2 Open 3D FLIM and corresponding LIGHTNING confocal images.
6.3.3 Under the Processing tab, select the concatenate function.
6.3.4 Select both 3D FLIM and LIGHTNING images to concatenate by channel.
6.3.5 Apply concatenation.
6.3.6 Deselect blue and green channels.
6.3.7 Set minimum intensity threshold to 40.
6.3.8 Using movie editor, export image in movie mode.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology expert specializing in Jurkat cell preparation, nucleofection, and live-cell imaging, structure the protocol into hierarchical steps with parameter inheritance. Ensure precise handling of reagents and instruments while maintaining experimental specifications.
instruction: Organize the protocol into multi-level steps with imperative verbs and consistent tense. Include all precise parameters and ensure logical flow between steps. Exclude theoretical explanations.
input: To quantify Piezo1 and actin polarity in Jurkat cells during chemokine stimulation using live-cell imaging. Available materials: Jurkat cells, RPMI medium, nucleofection solution, Piezo1-mCherry and Actin-GFP plasmids, ICAM-1, confocal dishes, flow cytometer, confocal microscope. How to prepare, transfect, and image cells?
output: 1. Jurkat Cell Preparation.
1.1. Passage Jurkat cells to achieve 0.1×10^6/mL density in RPMI medium.
1.2. Maintain cell density below 75% on the day of nucleofection.
1.3. Use cells within 10 passages post-revival.
2. Nucleofection of Plasmids.
2.1. Prepare post-nucleofection RPMI media in 6-well plates (2mL/well) at 37°C/5% CO2.
2.2. Warm RPMI media to 37°C.
2.3. Nucleofector System Setup.
2.3.1. Turn on Amaxa 4D-Nucleofector system 30min prior.
