3.4. Secondary Antibody Incubation and Washing.
3.4.1. Incubate at room temperature for 1 hour with the HRP-conjugated anti-mouse secondary antibody (1/10,000 dilution) into TBS-T 5% dry milk.
3.4.2. Wash with TBS-T for 5 minutes on a shaker and repeat the operation two times.
3.5. Signal Detection and Membrane Stripping.
3.5.1. Gently dry the membrane using paper towels and place it face up and flat on a sheet of plastic wrap.
3.5.2. Directly add the Immobilion Forte western substrate onto the whole membrane and detect chemiluminescence with the ChemiDoc imaging system.
3.5.3. Rinse the membrane in TBS-T and transfer in 5 mL of stripping buffer.
3.6. Tubulin Antibody Incubation and Detection.
3.6.1. Block the membrane with TBS-T 5% dry milk for 30 minutes at room temperature on gentle shaking.
3.6.2. Incubate at room temperature for 1 hour with the anti-tubulin antibody diluted into TBS-T 5% dry milk.
3.6.3. Detect chemiluminescence with the ChemiDoc imaging system.

system_prompt: As an expert in biochemical and molecular functional analysis, specializing in custom biomineralization of enzymes in metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), provide a hierarchical decomposition of the protocol into multi-level steps with parameter inheritance and coordination of reagents and instruments across steps.
instruction: Structure the protocol into a hierarchical format with imperative verbs, maintaining tense consistency. Include parameter inheritance across steps and ensure reagent and instrument continuity. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers. Exclude theoretical explanations.
input: To develop a custom biomineralization approach for enzyme immobilization in MOFs, enhancing stability and reusability. Available materials: double-deionized water (ddH2O), metal ions, ligands, enzymes. Instruments: powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA). How to prepare MOFs, co-crystallize enzymes, characterize composites, and assess functionality?
output: 1. Introduction and General Considerations.
1.1. Use double-deionized water (ddH2O) for all solutions and adjust pH with 1 M HCl or NaOH.
1.2. Store enzymes and enzyme@MOF composites at 4°C and deliver on ice prior to activity tests.
1.3. Follow equipment operation and data analysis according to users' manuals/guidance.
2. Metal Ion/Ligand Selection and Aqueous-Phase MOF Preparation.
2.1. Metal Ion/Ligand Selection.
2.1.1. Select metal ions and ligands based on published MOFs prepared via solvothermal or hydrothermal methods.
2.1.2. Consider enzyme stability, functionality, and potential toxicity during selection.
2.2. MOF Preparation.
2.2.1. Optimize MOF forming conditions, including metal:ligand ratio and reaction volume.
2.2.2. Improve ligand solubility in water by reacting with NaOH to prepare a salt-based ligand.
2.2.3. Form MOF by mixing metal ions and ligands in ddH2O under gentle nutation at room temperature.
2.2.4. Wash off unreacted species with EtOH or MeOH and store co-crystals at 4°C.
2.3. MOF Characterization.
2.3.1. Perform powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) to confirm crystal structure.
2.3.2. Use scanning electron microscope (SEM) to confirm morphology and size of co-crystals.
2.3.3. Conduct thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) to determine thermal stability.
2.3.4. Measure N2 isotherm to confirm porosity.
2.3.5. Test pH and thermal stability of MOFs.
3. Enzyme@MOF Composite Preparation.
3.1. Enzyme Preparation and Control Experiments.
3.1.1. Prepare enzymes according to manufacturer's instructions or literature protocols.
3.1.2. Perform positive control of enzyme activity to confirm enzyme functionality.
3.1.3. Perform negative controls of activity to confirm metal ions, ligands, and MOFs do not affect enzyme activity.
3.2. Enzyme@MOF Composite Preparation.
3.2.1. Mix enzymes with metal ions and ligands in ddH2O to form composites.
3.2.2. React at room temperature overnight under nutation and wash with EtOH at 4°C.
3.2.3. Store prepared enzyme@MOF composites at 4°C.
3.3. Enzyme@MOF Characterization.
3.3.1. Perform PXRD to confirm crystal structure of enzyme@MOF composites.
3.3.2. Use SEM to confirm morphology and size of enzyme@MOF composites.
3.3.3. Conduct TGA to determine thermal stability of enzyme@MOF composites.
3.3.4. Measure N2 isotherm to confirm porosity of enzyme@MOF composites.
3.3.5. Test pH and thermal stability of enzyme@MOF composites.
3.3.6. Perform enzyme activity assays to confirm functionality of encapsulated enzymes.
4. Data Analysis and Troubleshooting.
4.1. Analyze data from characterization techniques and activity assays.
4.2. Troubleshoot any issues with MOF formation, enzyme activity, or composite stability.

system_prompt: As a Plant Science & Technology expert specializing in seed collection and processing protocols, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To collect, extract, clean, and store high-quality Populus seeds for laboratory use and long-term storage. Available materials: paper bags, trays, bamboo sticks, mesh pencil cup, Petri dish, fine mesh kitchen strainer, glass vial, MS plates, laminar flow hood, climate-controlled chamber. How to efficiently collect and process seeds from Populus deltoides?
output: 1. Seed Collection.
1.1. Identify Mature Female Trees.
1.1.1. Identify mature female trees and monitor reproductive development carefully.
1.1.2. Note: Trees in the genus Populus are dioecious. Copious amounts of seeds are produced on mature female trees.
1.1.3. Flowers are arranged in flower clusters (catkins). After fertilization, catkins lengthen, and flowers develop into green fruit capsules carrying the developing and maturing seed.
1.1.4. Capsules split open when ripe and release seed with trichomes (cotton) for wind dispersal.
1.2. Collect Maturing Catkins.
1.2.1. Collect maturing catkins when the first few capsules begin to open.
1.2.2. Gently pick catkins from branches by breaking them off at the base.
1.2.3. Store catkins in paper bags.
1.3. Dry Collected Catkins.
1.3.1. Bring material indoors and spread out in trays.
1.3.2. Evenly distribute catkins in a single layer and avoid overlap of catkins to allow for rapid drying.
1.3.3. Keep in a dry place.
1.4. Cover Trays and Allow Seeds to Shed.
1.4.1. Cover trays very loosely with a lid to keep emerging cotton inside the tray while allowing for proper ventilation.
1.4.2. Note: It will take between one and seven days for seeds to shed, i.e., for cotton to emerge.
1.5. Extract Seeds.
1.5.1. Seed extraction should be done as soon as all capsules are open and cotton emerges.
1.5.2. Note: Tufts of long cellulose-rich hair are attached to the small, light seeds to enable wind dispersal.
2. Seed Extraction - Mechanical Extraction by Shaking.
2.1. Prepare Work Area and Seed Shaker.
2.1.1. Disinfect the surface of the work area and cover it completely with clean sheets of paper.
2.1.2. Assemble the seed shaker by placing 10-15 fresh pieces of bamboo sticks inside an autoclaved mesh pencil cup.
2.2. Transfer Cotton into Seed Shaker.
2.2.1. Transfer 0.5-1g of cotton into the shaker and cover it with a Petri dish lid.
2.2.2. Note: a. The cotton is the white fluff released from dry and mature catkins, which comprises seeds and attached hair.
2.3. Shake Seed Shaker and Extract Seeds.
2.3.1. Tilt the seed shaker to the side and shake vigorously by hand.
2.3.2. Seeds will fall out of the shaker and onto the paper sheets.
2.4. Gather Extracted Seeds.
2.4.1. Gather the extracted seeds from the paper sheets on the work surface, place them in a small container, and set them aside for subsequent cleaning steps.
3. Seed Cleaning.
3.1. Sieve Extracted Seeds.
3.1.1. Place the extracted seeds into a fine mesh kitchen strainer and sieve the material in a gentle circular motion.
3.1.2. Note: Small debris will pass through the sieve.
3.2. Remove Larger Debris.
3.2.1. Place seeds onto a single sheet of paper and manually remove larger pieces of debris with tweezers.
3.2.2. Some very small pieces of debris can be static and will adhere to the seed surface.
3.3. Transfer Seeds to Clean Glass Vial.
3.3.1. Transfer the seeds into a clean glass vial and store at -20°C.
3.3.2. Note: Seed storage conditions are critical.
4. Germination Test - To Assess Seed Quality.
4.1. Prepare MS plates.
4.1.1. Prepare MS plates as detailed under Recipes.
4.1.2. Work in a laminar flow hood and allow plates to solidify and dry.
4.2. Place Seeds on Plates.
4.2.1. Place seeds on a plate using sterilized tweezers and seal plates with micropore tape.
4.2.2. Work under a laminar flow hood.
4.3. Incubate Seeds.
4.3.1. Place plated seeds in a climate-controlled chamber under long-day conditions.
4.3.2. Count germinated seeds three days after plating and calculate germination efficiency.

system_prompt: As an expert in cell biology and culture techniques, specializing in the development of advanced human skin reconstruction models, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To develop a sustainable, reproducible human skin reconstruction model on immune-deficient mice. Available materials: fibroblasts, keratinocytes, fibrin hydrogel, silicone chambers, EpiLife medium, FEM medium. How to sequentially transplant cells, prepare working solutions, and perform histological analysis?
output: 1. Defrosting and Plating Keratinocytes.
1.1. Coat two 10cm tissue culture dishes with collagen.
1.2. Prepare complete EpiLife medium.
1.3. Thawing Keratinocytes.
1.3.1. Remove cryovial (5×10^5 frozen keratinocytes) from liquid nitrogen and place in 37°C water bath.
1.3.2. Thaw quickly, keeping cap above water level.
1.4. Plating Keratinocytes.
1.4.1. Transfer thawed keratinocytes into conical tube with 5mL complete EpiLife medium.
1.4.2. Centrifuge cells at 200×g for 5min at RT.
2. Subculturing Keratinocytes.
2.1. Prepare two 10cm tissue culture dishes and coat with bovine collagen.
2.2. Detaching Keratinocytes.
2.2.1. Add 3mL Accutase and incubate at 37°C for 6–9min.
2.2.2. Tap dish gently and add 3mL complete EpiLife medium to neutralize Accutase.
2.3. Plating Subcultured Keratinocytes.
2.3.1. Transfer 2.5–4.0×10^3 keratinocytes per cm^2 into each collagen-coated dish with pre-equilibrated EpiLife medium.
2.3.2. Gently and thoroughly disperse cells by alternating up/down and left/right motions.
3. Defrosting and Plating Fibroblasts.
3.1. Prepare complete FEM medium.
3.2. Thawing Fibroblasts.
3.2.1. Remove cryovial (5×10^5 frozen fibroblasts) from liquid nitrogen and place in 37°C water bath.
3.2.2. Thaw quickly, keeping cap above water level.
3.3. Plating Fibroblasts.
3.3.1. Transfer thawed fibroblasts into conical tube with 5mL complete FEM medium.
3.3.2. Centrifuge cells at 200×g for 5min at RT.
4. Subculturing Fibroblasts.
4.1. Prepare one 10cm tissue culture dish and allow Trypsin-EDTA and complete FEM medium to equilibrate to RT.
4.2. Detaching Fibroblasts.
4.2.1. Add 3mL Trypsin-EDTA and incubate at 37°C for 2-3min.
4.2.2. Tap dish gently and add 6mL complete FEM medium to neutralize Trypsin-EDTA.
4.3. Plating Subcultured Fibroblasts.
4.3.1. Transfer 2.5×10^3 fibroblasts per cm^2 to dish with pre-equilibrated FEM medium.
4.3.2. Gently and thoroughly disperse cells by alternating up/down and left/right motions.
5. Preparation of Working Solutions and Cells for Grafting.
5.1. Defrost thrombin stock solution overnight on ice at 4°C.
5.2. Defrost fibrinogen aliquot in fridge for 1h before use.
5.3. Preparing Cells for Grafting.
5.3.1. Collect 2.0×10^6 fibroblasts and resuspend pellet in 50µL complete FEM medium.
5.3.2. Collect 2.0×10^6 keratinocytes and resuspend pellet in 50µL complete EpiLife medium.
6. Grafting Procedure.
6.1. Administer anesthesia to mice via intraperitoneal injection with prepared anesthetic solution.
6.2. Insertion of Silicone Chamber.
6.2.1. Cut piece of skin with curved scissors to create round incision, 1cm in size.
6.2.2. Apply 200µL sterile DPBS with antibiotics onto opened muscle fascia.
6.3. Delivery of Cell Suspension.
6.3.1. Transfer entire volume of cold working Solution 1 into tube containing suspended fibroblasts.
6.3.2. Add 9.4µL 25U/mL thrombin and 17.3µL 40mg/mL fibrinogen to cell suspension.
7. Delivery of Gel Containing Keratinocytes.
7.1. Transfer entire volume of cold working Solution 2 into tube containing keratinocyte suspension.
7.2. Adding Thrombin and Fibrinogen.
7.2.1. Add 9.4µL 25U/mL thrombin and 17.3µL 40mg/mL fibrinogen to cell suspension.
7.2.2. Resuspend gently by pipetting 2–3 times, avoiding bubbles.
8. Chamber Removal, Wound Healing, and Skin Graft Maturation.
8.1. Administer anesthesia to mice via intraperitoneal injection with prepared anesthetic solution.
8.2. Removing the Chamber.
8.2.1. Loosen skin around chamber with sterile forceps.
8.2.2. Gently squeeze dome of silicone chamber and carefully pull one side from under skin.
9. Histological Examination of Human Skin Xenografts.
9.1. Euthanize mouse on harvesting day per approved protocol.
9.2. Fixing and Sectioning.
9.2.1. Fix sections with skin grafts in 10% Formalin for 24h.
9.2.2. Transfer to 70% ethanol.
9.3. Staining and Analysis.
9.3.1. Confirm presence of human skin graft through histological analysis with H&E staining.
9.3.2. Conduct immunohistochemical analysis following Yanez et al. (2015) protocol.

system_prompt: As an expert in plant science and technology, specializing in rapid on-site detection techniques for Fusarium oxysporum using RPA-LFD, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent coordination while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To develop a rapid on-site detection technique for Fusarium oxysporum using RPA-LFD. Available materials: DNAMAN v6.0.3.99, primers, probes, DNA extraction solutions, PDA plates, RPA buffers, HybriDetect LFD. How to design primers, extract DNA, optimize reaction conditions, and detect Fusarium oxysporum in plant samples?
output: 1. Design of Primers and Probes.
1.1 Use DNAMAN v6.0.3.99 to design primers based on the CYP51C sequence of common Fusarium species.
1.2 Design specific primers for F. oxysporum using the CYP51C gene sequence.
1.3 Primer Design Specifications.
1.3.1 Recommended primer length is between 31 and 32 bp.
1.3.2 Design primer pairs, such as F91 and R91, with a biotin label on the 5' end of the downstream primer.
1.4 Probe Design.
1.4.1 Design a probe with an antigen marker (6-FAM) modification at the 5' end and a modified group (C3 Spacer) at the 3' end.
1.4.2 Include a dSpacer (tetrahydrofuran, THF) labeled at the middle of the 5' and 3' ends as the recognition site for NFO.
2. DNA Extraction.
2.1 Culture Fusarium species isolates in a PDA plate at 28°C until the colony diameter reaches 6cm.
2.2 Scrape the mycelium into a 1.5mL tube, add quartz sand and CTAB extracting solution, and grind for 120s.
2.3 DNA Extraction Procedure.
2.3.1 Add CTAB extracting solution and shake for 15s using a vortex.
2.3.2 Add trichloromethane, shake for 15s, and centrifuge at 13,800×g for 10min.
2.3.3 Remove the supernatant, add isopropanol, and centrifuge at 13,800×g for 10min.
2.3.4 Discard the supernatant, add 70% ethanol, and centrifuge at 13,800×g for 5min.
2.3.5 Discard the supernatant, dry the tube, and add ddH2O.
3. Specific Detection of Primers and Probes.
3.1 Set up the reaction system with Buffer A, upstream and downstream primers, probe, and template DNA.
3.2 Incubate at 38°C for 10min.
3.3 Reaction Product Processing.
3.3.1 Dilute the reaction product 20 times using ddH2O.
3.3.2 Add the diluted reaction product to the sample hole of HybriDetect LFD.
3.4 Test Result Interpretation.
3.4.1 If the control line is visible and the detection line is not, it indicates a negative result.
3.4.2 If both the detection and control lines are visible, it indicates a positive result.
4. RPA-LFD Reaction Condition Optimization.
4.1 Temperature Optimization.
4.1.1 Set the reaction temperature to 33, 36, 39, 42, and 45°C.
4.1.2 Determine the optimal reaction temperature based on the color depth of the detection line.
4.2 Time Optimization.
4.2.1 Set the reaction time to 4, 6, 8, 10, and 12min.
4.2.2 Determine the optimal reaction time based on the color depth of the detection line.
5. Detection System Sensitivity Verification.
5.1 Set the DNA concentration to 10ng/μL, 1ng/μL, 100pg/μL, 10pg/μL, 1pg/μL, and 100fg/μL.
5.2 Add different concentrations of DNA templates to the reaction system.
5.3 Incubate at 39°C for 8min and visualize the amplification results.
5.4 Determine the detection limit based on the presence or absence of the detection line.
6. Field Sample Detection.
6.1 Take 100mg of strawberry crown tissue and place it in a 1.5mL tube.
6.2 Add 100μL of 60% PEG200 and incubate at room temperature for 15min.
6.3 RPA Reaction Setup.
6.3.1 Add the lysate supernatant as a template into the RPA reaction system.
6.3.2 Set up the reaction system with Buffer A, upstream and downstream primers, probe, and template DNA.
6.4 Test Result Interpretation.
6.4.1 If the control line is visible and the detection line is not, it indicates that the strawberry was not infected by F. oxysporum.
6.4.2 If both the detection and control lines are visible, it indicates that the strawberry was infected by F. oxysporum.

system_prompt: As an Immunological Techniques expert specializing in the expansion and polarization of human γδT17 cells, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and coordination of reagents/instruments across steps while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/instrument continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers, ensuring each step begins with a verb.
input: To study the in vitro expansion and polarization of human γδT17 cells from peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Available materials: Human γδTCR Ab (IMMU510, IM1349), RPMI-1640 medium, FBS, Penicillin-Streptomycin, Ficoll, Trypan blue, IL-7, PMA, Ionomycin, GolgiPlug, and flow cytometry equipment. How to expand and polarize γδT17 cells for studying their role in immunity?
output: 1. Make Complete RPMI-1640 Medium.
1.1. Combine RPMI-1640 medium with ~10% FBS, 1% Penicillin-Streptomycin, and ~2-Mercaptoethanol (0.1mL/L).
2. Make Anti-Human γδTCR Solution.
2.1. Dissolve 0.1 mg of human γδTCR Ab in 500uL of PBS to make 0.2 ug/uL solution.
3. Make Viability Dye Stock.
3.1. Mix 1uL of viability dye with 49uL of PBS (1:49 dilution).
4. Make 1× Wash Buffer.
4.1. Dilute 10× wash buffer 1:9 with H2O.
5. Draw Peripheral Blood.
5.1. Collect ~15-20mL of blood from healthy donors using EDTA-K2 tubes.
6. Dilute Blood Samples.
6.1. Mix blood with equal volume of RPMI-1640 medium.
7. Layer Blood over Ficoll.
7.1. Add 5mL diluted blood over 5mL Ficoll in a 15mL tube.
8. Centrifuge Blood Suspension.
8.1. Spin at 931×g for 15min at room temperature without brakes.
8.2. Transfer mononuclear cell layer to new tube.
9. Wash and Resuspend Cells.
9.1. Add 10mL of complete RPMI-1640 medium to the tube.
9.2. Gently mix and centrifuge at 524×g for 10min at 4°C.
9.3. Remove supernatant by pipetting.
10. Count Cell Numbers.
10.1. Resuspend cell pellet in 5mL medium and count using hemocytometer or Trypan blue.
11. Coat 24-Well Plate with γδTCR Ab.
11.1. Add 245uL PBS and 5uL 0.2 ug/uL γδTCR Ab per well.
11.2. Incubate overnight at 37°C with 5% CO2.
12. Seed PBMCs into 24-Well Plate.
12.1. Dilute PBMCs to appropriate concentration with complete RPMI-1640 medium containing 20ng/mL IL-7.
12.2. Seed 1-4 million cells per well in 1mL medium.
13. Culture Cells for Expansion.
13.1. Check cells daily under microscope for contamination.
13.2. Passage cells to new 6-well plate on day 3-4 using complete medium with IL-7.
13.3. Culture for 2-3 weeks (4-5 passages).
14. Collect and Stain Cells.
14.1. Collect 1mL cell medium by pipetting.
14.2. Perform intracellular cytokine staining for IL-17.
15. Stimulate Cells with PMA and Ionomycin.
15.1. Stimulate 100,000 cells with PMA (50ng/mL), ionomycin (1ug/mL), and GolgiPlug.
15.2. Incubate for 4-6h at 37°C with 5% CO2.
16. Collect and Process Cells.
16.1. Transfer cell suspension to 12×75 mm tubes.
16.2. Add TruStain FcX (5uL/test) and incubate at 4°C for 10min.
16.3. Add surface antibodies and incubate at 4°C for 30min.
17. Fix and Wash Cells.
17.1. Add 400uL fixation buffer per tube and vortex.
17.2. Fix cells at room temperature for 20min in dark.
18. Analyze by Flow Cytometry.
18.1. Acquire data on FACSCanto II flow cytometer.
18.2. Analyze data using FlowJo software.

system_prompt: As a Neuroscience Methods expert specializing in compartmentalized neuronal cultures and microfluidic chamber applications, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To study polarized neurons using compartmentalized microfluidic chambers, enabling precise spatial control and compatibility with microscopy techniques. Available materials: PDMS, epoxy molds, PDL, laminin, MEM-HS, Neurobasal-B27, f-Ctb, BDNF, Alexa Fluor 555 transferrin. How to prepare microfluidic chambers, culture cortical neurons, perform retrograde transport, and conduct immunofluorescence labeling?
output: 1. Preparation and Attachment of PDMS Microfluidic Chambers to Glass Coverslips.
1.1. Prepare Microfluidic Chambers.
1.1.1. Blow dust off epoxy molds using pressurized air/N2.
1.1.2. Keep mold plates closed with parafilm until casting.
1.1.3. Prepare PDMS mixture at a 1:10 ratio.
1.1.4. Pour PDMS mixture into molds and place in vacuum desiccator for 2-3 hours.
1.1.5. Move molds into a 70°C oven for at least 3 hours.
1.1.6. Incise PDMS cast along mold edge with a scalpel.
1.1.7. Punch four 5mm holes in PDMS for media flux.
1.1.8. Cut multi-chamber molds into single chambers using a blade.
1.1.9. Store chambers in a Petri dish covered with parafilm.
1.2. Prepare Glass Coverslips and Chambers Prior to Neuronal Seeding.
1.2.1. Add 8cm² parafilm to a sterile 150mm×25mm culture dish.
1.2.2. Place 25mm No. 1 glass coverslips on parafilm.
1.2.3. Coat coverslips with 500µL PDL-laminin mixture and incubate overnight.
1.2.4. Wash chambers with 2% Micro90 detergent in distilled water for 5 minutes.
1.2.5. Rinse chambers six times with distilled water.
1.2.6. Sterilize chambers with 100% ethanol for 10 minutes.
1.3. Mount Chamber on Cover.
1.3.1. Place coverslips in a laminar flow hood.
1.3.2. Remove PDL-laminin mixture with a p1000 pipette.
1.3.3. Wash coverslips three times with autoclaved distilled water.
1.3.4. Dry coverslips with a vacuum until completely dry.
1.3.5. Irradiate chambers and coverslips with UV light for 5 minutes.
1.3.6. Attach chamber to coverslip, adjusting to the edge and gently sealing.
1.3.7. Place assembled chambers in a 35mm dish or 6-well plate.
2. Primary Culture of Cortical Neurons and Plating Neurons in Microfluidic Chambers.
2.1. Primary Cultures of Cortical Neurons.
2.1.1. Place embryos in 10mL HBSS on ice.
2.1.2. Decapitate embryos and place heads in HBSS.
2.1.3. Expose brain by removing skin and skull.
2.1.4. Remove brain and place in HBSS on ice.
2.1.5. Separate brain hemispheres and remove meninges.
2.1.6. Dissect cortex into 0.5-1mm² pieces and add to HBSS.
2.1.7. Digest tissue with HBSS-trypsin solution for 10 minutes at 37°C.
2.1.8. Wash cortex pieces three times with HBSS.
2.1.9. Resuspend cortex in MEM-HS and dissociate with pipettes.
2.2. Plating Neurons in Microfluidic Chambers.
2.2.1. Count cells in a Neubauer chamber.
2.2.2. Adjust cell concentration with MEM-HS via centrifugation.
2.2.3. Remove MEM-HS from chamber holes.
2.2.4. Add 5µL MEM-HS with 50×10³ cells to the chamber.
2.2.5. Allow neurons to attach for 30 minutes.
2.2.6. Add 60µL MEM-HS to each punch hole.
2.2.7. Replace media with Neurobasal-B27 + AraC in cell body and axonal compartments the next day.
3. Retrograde Transport of Fluorescently Labeled f-Ctb in Compartmentalized Cortical Neurons.
3.1. Confirmation of Compartmentalization and Retrograde Labeling.
3.1.1. Treat cultures with f-Ctb674 in axonal compartment overnight.
3.1.2. Replace media with Neurobasal-B27 + f-Ctb555 in axonal compartment.
3.1.3. Incubate cells overnight.
3.1.4. Wash f-Ctb674 and add f-Ctb555 for 30-180 minutes.
3.2. Fixation and Immunostaining.
3.2.1. Remove media and wash chambers with PBS.
3.2.2. Fix neurons with PFA solution for 18 minutes.
3.2.3. Wash three times with PBS.
3.2.4. Stain with Hoechst solution for 10 minutes.
4. Immunofluorescence and Multiple Labeling of Compartmentalized Cortical Neurons.
4.1. Multiple Labeling of f-Ctb, Endocytic Structures, and βIII-tubulin.
4.1.1. Replace media with Neurobasal-B27.
4.1.2. Incubate for 3 hours.
4.1.3. Wash neurons with PBS.
4.1.4. Fix with PFA solution for 18 minutes.
4.1.5. Wash three times with PBS.
4.1.6. Block with blocking solution for 1 hour.
4.1.7. Incubate with primary antibodies overnight.
5. Labeling Signaling Endosomes with Biotinylated BDNF.
5.1. Conjugation of Biotinylated BDNF with Streptavidin.
5.1.1. Dissolve BDNF-biotin in neurobasal media with 0.1% BSA.
5.1.2. Resuspend streptavidin DyLight 488 in neurobasal media.
5.1.3. Mix BDNF-biotin and streptavidin solutions.
5.1.4. Incubate for 20 minutes at 37°C.
5.2. Multilabeling Neuronal Endosomes.
5.2.1. Culture neurons until DIV 8.
5.2.2. Replace media with TrkB-fc in cell body compartment.
5.2.3. Add f-Ctb647 and f-BDNF488 to axonal compartment for 180 minutes.
5.2.4. Replace media with f-transferrin 555 in cell body compartment for 30 minutes.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology & Culture expert specializing in the function of tears on corneal epithelial cells, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To examine the function of tears on corneal epithelial cells, how to set up an in vitro assay using patient-isolated tears and human corneal limbal epithelial (HCLE) cells. Available materials: cryopreserved HCLE cells, MEM+10% FBS media, KSFM+GF media, TrypLE solution, Schirmer strips, 1×PBS, NanoDrop spectrophotometer, gelatin zymography reagents, RNA lysis buffer, and real-time PCR system. What steps are required to culture, treat, and analyze HCLE cells?
output: 1. Culturing and Seeding of HCLE Cells.
1.1. Remove a vial of cryopreserved HCLE cells from -80°C.
1.2. Place the vial at 37°C for 3-4 minutes to thaw the cells.
1.3. Cell Preparation.
1.3.1. Add 1 mL of the cryopreserved cells to 5 mL of MEM+10% FBS media in a 15 mL centrifuge tube in a BSL2 safety cabinet.
1.3.2. Centrifuge at 160×g for 5 minutes at room temperature.
1.3.3. Discard the supernatant.
1.3.4. Resuspend the pellet in 1 mL of KSFM+GF media.
1.4. Cell Seeding.
1.4.1. Add the resuspended cells to a 100 mm tissue culture plate and add 7 mL of fresh KSFM+GF media.
1.4.2. Incubate the cells at 37°C with 5% CO2 in the incubator to grow.
1.5. Cell Passaging.
1.5.1. Once the cells attain 70% confluency, passage the cells twice before seeding for experiment.
1.5.2. For passaging the cells, remove the spent media from the 100 mm tissue culture plate.
1.5.3. Wash the plate with 4 mL of 1× Dulbecco’s PBS.
1.5.4. Add 1 mL of TrypLE solution to the plate and incubate at 37°C with 5% CO2 for 3-5 minutes.
2. Collection of Tears from PED Patients.
2.1. A Schirmer strip test is used to collect tears.
2.2. Tear Collection Procedure.
2.2.1. Wear gloves and fold the end of the Schirmer strip within the packet at the ungraduated end.
2.2.2. Remove the Schirmer strip from the opposite end, place the folded end inside the lower lid of both eyes, and ask the patient to close their eyes.
2.2.3. After 5 minutes, the Schirmer strips are removed from both eyes.
2.3. Tear Storage.
2.3.1. Collect the strips and place the entire strip containing the adsorbed tears in a 1.5 mL microcentrifuge tube (MCT) labeled with complete patient information.
2.3.2. Post tear collection, immediately place the tubes on ice.
3. Extraction of Proteins from Tears of Patients.
3.1. Thaw tear vials on ice.
3.2. Protein Extraction Procedure.
3.2.1. Add 200 μL of 1×PBS to each vial using a 200 μL pipette.
3.2.2. With the help of a 1,000 μL pipette tip, grind the Schirmer strips in the MCTs.
3.2.3. Vortex for 30 seconds using a vortexer and then incubate on ice for 2 minutes.
3.3. Protein Quantification.
3.3.1. Quantify proteins by measuring absorbance at 280 nm using NanoDrop.
3.3.2. For protein concentration measurement by NanoDrop, first set blank with 1 μL of 1× PBS using a 2.5 μL pipette.
4. Seeding of HCLE Cells for the Experiment.
4.1. Use the previously prepared 100 mm tissue culture dishes of HCLE cells at 70% confluency for seeding the experiment.
4.2. Cell Preparation.
4.2.1. Discard the spent KSFM media from the culture dish using a 10 mL serological pipette in a BSL2 safety cabinet.
4.2.2. Wash the plate once with 3-4 mL of 1× Dulbecco’s PBS using a 1,000 μL pipette.
4.3. Cell Seeding.
4.3.1. Add 1.5 mL of TrypLE solution to the plate after removing 1×PBS from the plate using a 1,000 μL pipette and incubate the plate at 37°C for 5 minutes in a CO2 incubator.
4.3.2. Take out the plate from the CO2 incubator post incubation and tap the plate on both sides to dislodge the trypsinized cells.
5. Treating HCLE Cells with Proteins Isolated from Tears.
5.1. Once the density reaches 60%-70% confluency, approximately 20 hours after seeding, treat cells with tear proteins.
5.2. Tear Protein Treatment.
5.2.1. Remove the complete media from each well of the 12-well seeded plate using a 1,000 μL pipette.
5.2.2. Wash the cells once with 500 μL of 1×PBS to remove the remaining growth factors.
5.3. Cell Incubation.
5.3.1. Add 1 mL of incomplete KSFM-GF media to each well using a 1,000 μL pipette.
5.3.2. Add an equal concentration of control and test tear proteins to the respective wells in a drop-wise manner.
6. Analysis of MMP Activity using Gelatin Zymography.
6.1. After 48 hours, collect the culture supernatant of both the control and tear protein–treated cells in 1.5 mL Eppendorf tubes to check the activity of MMPs by gelatin zymography.
6.2. Gel Preparation.
6.2.1. Prepare an 8% acrylamide gel using 40% acrylamide, TEMED, 2.5× Tris-SDS buffer (pH 8.8), 5× Tris-SDS buffer (pH 6.8), and APS incorporated with 1 mg/mL of gelatin prepared in water.
6.2.2. Load the protein sample made with NuPage sample buffer (1×) and the pre-stained protein ladder onto the gel.
6.3. Gel Running and Staining.
6.3.1. Run the gel at 30 mA for 1.5 hours using the mini gel tank apparatus.
6.3.2. When the dye has completely run off, stop running the gel.
7. Gene Expression Analysis of Tear Protein–Treated HCLE Cells.
7.1. Lyse cells in RNA lysis buffer and isolate RNA from the cells using Qiagen Mini-RNA Isolation kit, following the manufacturer’s instructions.
7.2. RNA Quantification.
7.2.1. Quantify the RNA concentration by measuring absorbance at 260 nm using a NanoDrop.
7.2.2. Use the elution buffer provided in the RNA Isolation kit to set a blank for quantifying RNA.
7.3. Real-Time PCR.
7.3.1. Perform real-time PCR analysis of the samples in duplicates using SYBR Green on an Azure Biosystems qPCR system.
7.3.2. Run the housekeeping genes β-actin and RPL10 to study the effect on proinflammatory cytokines.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology & Culture expert specializing in immunofluorescence-based quantification of cell proliferation during caudal fin regeneration in African killifish, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/instrument coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/instrument continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To quantify cell proliferation dynamics during caudal fin regeneration in African killifish using immunofluorescence. Available materials: MS-222, PBS-Tween, primary and secondary antibodies, DCM, OCT, ProLong Gold antifade mountant, confocal microscope. How to collect, fix, stain, and image whole-mount and cryosectioned caudal fin samples?
output: 1. Sample Collection and Fixation.
1.1. Anesthetize and Prepare Fish.
1.1.1. Prepare 200mL of 100-150mg/L MS-222 in fish system water.
1.1.2. Catch fish using an appropriate net and place into the beaker.
1.1.3. Anesthetize fish for at least 5 minutes and transfer to a Petri dish using a plastic spoon.
1.2. Amputate Caudal Fin.
1.2.1. Amputate the caudal fin using a sterile razor blade.
1.2.2. Remove 50% of the fin area for simplicity.
1.3. Euthanize Fish.
1.3.1. Euthanize fish according to animal care protocols.
1.3.2. Perform euthanasia using hypothermic shock.
1.4. Fixation.
1.4.1. Pour 20mL of fixative into a Petri dish.
1.4.2. Transfer the fin sample to the fixative.
1.4.3. Incubate overnight at 4°C or 2h at room temperature.
1.5. Washing.
1.5.1. Wash with 20mL of PBS-Tween three times for 15 minutes each.
2. Permeabilization and Bleaching (Whole Mount).
2.1. Permeabilization.
2.1.1. Transfer samples to a polypropylene jar.
2.1.2. Incubate with 10mL of PBS-Tween-NaN3 for 12h at room temperature.
2.2. Dehydration.
2.2.1. Incubate in 25% MetOH for 4h.
2.2.2. Incubate in 50% MetOH for 4h.
2.2.3. Incubate in 75% MetOH for 4h.
2.2.4. Incubate in 100% MetOH overnight.
2.3. Bleaching.
2.3.1. Incubate in bleaching solution for 12h under white light.
2.3.2. Repeat with fresh solution until desired bleaching.
2.4. Rehydration.
2.4.1. Incubate in 50% MetOH for 4h.
2.4.2. Incubate in 25% MetOH for 4h.
2.4.3. Wash with 10mL of PBS-Tween-NaN3 overnight.
3. Staining (Whole Mount).
3.1. Blocking.
3.1.1. Incubate in 10mL of blocking solution for 24h.
3.2. Primary Antibody Incubation.
3.2.1. Incubate in 10mL of primary antibody solution for 24h.
3.3. Secondary Antibody Incubation.
3.3.1. Incubate in 10mL of secondary antibody solution for 24h.
3.4. Nuclear Staining.
3.4.1. Incubate in 10mL of nuclear dye solution for 24h.
4. Clearing (Whole Mount).
4.1. Dehydration.
4.1.1. Incubate in 25% MetOH for 4h.
4.1.2. Incubate in 50% MetOH for 4h.
4.1.3. Incubate in 75% MetOH for 4h.
4.1.4. Incubate in 100% MetOH for 4h.
4.2. Clearing.
4.2.1. Incubate in DCM-MetOH solution for 3h.
4.2.2. Incubate in DCM for 15 minutes.
4.2.3. Repeat until sample sinks.
4.3. Storage.
4.3.1. Store in 100% MetOH at -20°C.
5. Mounting (Whole Mount).
5.1. Resin Preparation.
5.1.1. Heat DER 332 in a 60°C oven for 30 minutes.
5.1.2. Mix resin components in a 50mL conical tube.
5.2. Sample Mounting.
5.2.1. Transfer sample to Kimwipe to remove excess DCM.
5.2.2. Transfer to Eppendorf tube with DBE and incubate for 15 minutes.
5.2.3. Replace DBE and leave overnight.
5.3. Curing.
5.3.1. Pour resin to fill coverslip.
5.3.2. Incubate in dark for 12h.
5.3.3. Pour additional resin to submerge sample.
6. Cryosectioning (Cryosections).
6.1. Sample Preparation.
6.1.1. Remove excess tissue.
6.1.2. Soak in 30% sucrose overnight.
6.2. Embedding.
6.2.1. Transfer to OCT mold.
6.2.2. Equilibrate in OCT for 30 minutes.
6.3. Sectioning.
6.3.1. Cut 10-12μm thick sections.
6.3.2. Transfer sections to microscope slides.
7. Staining and Mounting (Cryosections).
7.1. Blocking.
7.1.1. Block with 500μL of PBS-Tween solution for 1h.
7.2. Immunolabeling.
7.2.1. Incubate with 200μL of TrueBlack solution for 1 minute.
7.2.2. Incubate with 500μL of primary antibodies for 1h.
7.3. Secondary Antibody Incubation.
7.3.1. Incubate with 500μL of secondary antibodies for 1h.
7.4. Nuclear Staining.
7.4.1. Stain nuclei with 500μL of nuclear dye solution for 1h.
7.5. Mounting.
7.5.1. Add one drop of ProLong Gold.
7.5.2. Mount coverslip and cure overnight.
8. Imaging (Both Whole Mount and Cryosections).
8.1. Whole Mount Imaging.
8.1.1. Use 10× air objective on confocal microscope.
8.1.2. Collect slices every 5μm.
8.2. Cryosection Imaging.
8.2.1. Use 40× immersion objective on confocal microscope.
8.2.2. Collect slices every 1μm.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology and Culture expert specializing in the dissociation and culture of adult mouse satellite glial cells (SGCs), demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and reagent coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To dissociate and culture adult mouse satellite glial cells (SGCs) from dorsal root ganglia (DRGs) with high purity. Available materials: HBSS dissociation solution, papain, collagenase, DMEM culture medium, 70% ethanol, isoflurane, cell strainers. How to prepare, dissect, dissociate, and culture SGCs from DRGs?
output: 1. Initial Preparations.
1.1. Disinfect all surgical tools and working areas with 70°C ethanol.
1.2. Prepare a culture dish with 4mL of HBSS dissociation solution and two microtubes with 1mL of HBSS dissociation solution each, placed on ice at 4°C.
1.3. Prepare papain and collagenase solutions and keep them at 4°C. Warm these solutions and DMEM culture medium to 37°C just before use.
1.4. Terminally anesthetize a mouse using isoflurane and ensure complete anesthesia by checking for a lack of response to a pinch of the rear footpad.
1.5. Decapitate the mice to facilitate tissue dissection.
2. Tissue Dissection.
2.1. Move the mouse to a tissue dissection area and liberally spray the back fur with 70°C ethanol.
2.2. Make a large transverse cut in the middle of the back skin and pull the skin in opposite directions to remove all of the back skin.
2.3. Remove the back muscles by making two long cuts close to the left and right sides of the spinal column and pulling away the muscles.
2.4. Perform a laminectomy to expose the spinal cord and DRGs by removing the top of the vertebral canal.
2.5. Remove the spinal cord and expose the DRGs. Discard the spinal cord.
2.6. Grasp the dorsal root with forceps, carefully pull it, and cut the spinal nerve. Cut the dorsal root and place the collected DRGs in the culture dish on ice.
2.7. Remove any extra nerves, roots, and connective tissues from the DRGs under a stereomicroscope and transfer the cleaned DRGs into microtubes.
3. Cell Dissociation.
3.1. Centrifuge the microtubes containing the cleaned DRGs and remove the HBSS dissociation solution.

3.2. First Enzymatic Dissociation.     3.2.1. Add papain solution to the microtubes and incubate for 20 minutes in a 37°C water bath.     3.2.2. Gently flick the microtubes to resuspend the DRGs. Note: Do not resuspend with a pipette or vigorously shake to maintain cell integrity.
3.3. Centrifuge the microtubes and remove the papain solution.
3.4. Wash the DRGs with HBSS dissociation solution and centrifuge.

3.5. Second Enzymatic Dissociation.     3.5.1. Add collagenase solution to the microtubes and incubate for 20 minutes in a 37°C still water bath.     3.5.2. Gently flick the microtubes to resuspend the DRGs. Note: Do not resuspend with a pipette or vigorously shake to maintain cell integrity.
3.6. Centrifuge the microtubes and remove the collagenase solution.
3.7. Resuspend the DRGs in DMEM culture medium and centrifuge.

3.8. Mechanical Dissociation.     3.8.1. Resuspend the DRGs in DMEM culture medium and perform trituration using a P1000 pipette until the solution becomes cloudy.     3.8.2. Be gentle and avoid introducing air bubbles during trituration.
3.9. Add DMEM culture medium to each microtube and transfer the contents into a 50mL conical tube.
3.10. Filter the mixture using cell strainers and collect the filtrate.
4. Cell Plating and Growth.
4.1. Transfer the resuspended cells into a 12-well microplate and incubate in a CO2 cell culture incubator.
4.2. Replace the DMEM culture medium with fresh medium to remove cell debris.
4.3. Maintain SGC cultures by replacing the DMEM culture medium every 2-3 days and monitoring cell proliferation and morphology.

system_prompt: As an expert in Cell Biology and Culture, specializing in automated cell processing and cryopreservation methods, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while adhering to good laboratory practices for scalable cell therapy production.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers. Include precise parameters and ensure compatibility with automated systems.
input: To develop a scalable and consistent method for processing and cryopreserving cell therapy products, particularly mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Available materials: Finia® Fill and Finish System, controlled-rate freezers, cryopreservation media (Cryostor CS-10), and cell culture media (XSFM). How to automate cell processing, validate cell quality, and ensure reproducible cryopreservation?
output: 1. Introduction and Safety Precautions.
1.1 Perform all cell handling procedures in a biosafety cabinet (BSC).
1.2 The Finia system does not require the use of a BSC.
2. Cell Thawing (Cryopreserved Cells, MSCs).
2.1 Thaw XSFM media at 4°C overnight prior to use.
2.2 Prepare fresh media by adding 1% penicillin/streptomycin (P/S) to XSFM.
2.3 Retrieve a vial of frozen cells from LN2 storage.
2.4 Thaw the vial in a 37°C water bath for 2 minutes.
2.5 Transfer the cells to a 50mL conical tube and wash the vial with 1mL of fresh media.
2.6 Resuspend the cells and perform a cell count using the NucleoCounter.
2.7 Centrifuge the cell suspension at 500× g for 5 minutes.
2.8 Resuspend the pellet in media to achieve a concentration of 1-2.5×10^6 cells/mL.
2.9 Transfer the cells to a HYPERFlask and ensure even distribution.
3. Cell Expansion and Harvest.
3.1 Monitor confluence daily using microscopy.
3.2 Replace media by pouring 50mL into a conical tube.
3.3 Add 50mL of TrypLE 1× to the flask and incubate for 5 minutes.
3.4 Harvest cells by gently pouring the contents into two 50mL tubes.
3.5 Centrifuge the tubes at 500× g for 10 minutes.
3.6 Resuspend the cell pellet and perform a cell count using the NucleoCounter.
4. Cell Preparation (Fresh Cells, PBMCs).
4.1 Prepare 100mL of dilution buffer and bring Lymphoprep to room temperature.
4.2 Layer the diluted blood preparation over Lymphoprep and centrifuge at 800× g for 20 minutes.
4.3 Collect the buffy coat and wash the PBMCs with dilution buffer.
4.4 Perform a cell count using the NucleoCounter.
5. Preparation of the Finia System.
5.1 Log into the Cell Processing Application (CPA) software.
5.2 Create a custom protocol and configure materials with specific gravity and barcodes.
5.3 Check the load sensor by testing the 0-gram setting and 500g test weight.
6. Separation of Cells into Bags.
6.1 Calculate the amount of Cryostor CS-10 required based on cell count.
6.2 Prepare cryolabels with donor information and cell concentration.
6.3 Resuspend the cell pellet in Cryostor CS-10 and transfer into a syringe.
6.4 Connect the transfer bag to the Finia disposable set and start the procedure.
6.5 Remove the product bags and QC bag from the system.
6.6 Open the QC bag and aliquot contents into cryovials for downstream analysis.
7. Cryopreservation of Cells.
7.1 Label product bags and place into stainless-steel canisters.
7.2 Place canisters into an adjustable freezing rack and label QC cryovials.
7.3 Perform freezing operations using a controlled-rate freezer set to the desired program.
7.4 Transfer the canisters to a frame and store in LN2 vapor phase at -140°C to -180°C.
8. Cell Phenotype Analysis by Flow Cytometry.
8.1 Thaw and record pre-and post-spin cell counts on MSCs and PBMCs.
8.2 Add 1×10^5 cells per well into a 96-well V-bottom plate with technical replicates and FMO controls.
8.3 Centrifuge the plate at 500× g for 5 minutes and decant supernatant.
8.4 Resuspend cell pellets in viability stain solution or PBS for controls.
8.5 Incubate for 15 minutes at room temperature in the dark.
8.6 Perform a wash by resuspending cells in FC buffer.
8.7 Centrifuge the plate at 500× g for 5 minutes and decant supernatant.
8.8 For PBMC staining only, add 50uL of Fc block solution per well and incubate for 5 minutes.
8.9 Resuspend cell pellets in surface marker stain mixture and incubate for 20 minutes at 4°C.
8.10 Centrifuge the plate at 500× g for 5 minutes and decant supernatant.
8.11 Resuspend all cell pellets in BD CytofixTM fixation buffer and incubate for 15 minutes at 4°C.
8.12 Centrifuge the plate at 500× g for 5 minutes and decant supernatant.
8.13 Resuspend all cell pellets in FC buffer and perform data acquisition on the flow cytometer.

system_prompt: As an expert in embryonic tissue isolation and analysis, specializing in enzymatic techniques and three-dimensional explant culture, I will provide a structured protocol for isolating and analyzing embryonic hypothalamic tissue using multiplex hybridisation chain reaction.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain consistent tense, and ensure continuity of reagents and instruments across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To isolate and analyze embryonic hypothalamic tissue using enzymatic methods. Available materials include fertilized eggs, L-15 medium, Dispase, collagen, Matrigel, and required instruments such as forceps, tungsten needles, and tissue chopper. How to perform enzymatic isolation and establish 3D explant culture for analysis?
output: 1. Remove the embryo from the egg.
1.1 Incubate embryos in a 37°C incubator to appropriate HH stage.
1.2 Window the eggshell and peel away outer and inner shell membranes and vitelline membrane using fine scissors and No. 5 fine-tipped forceps.
1.3 Cut around the embryo and lift out, placing it in ice-cold L-15 medium in a 10 cm Petri dish.
1.4 Remove the chorioallantoic membrane and any contaminating yolk, transferring the embryo to clean L-15 medium in a 30mm Petri dish.
1.5 Cut away excess extra-embryonic tissue using Vannas scissors or an electrolytically sharpened tungsten needle.
1.6 If required, analyze a small piece of embryonic tissue by PCR to determine sex.
2. Isolate the hypothalamus.
2.1 Trim the embryo in cold L-15 medium to isolate anterior embryonic regions.
2.2 Transfer the anterior embryonic region into 0.5mL of freshly made Dispase in L-15 medium.
2.3 Incubate for a stage-dependent duration, observing the embryos until the tissue layers begin to visibly separate.
2.4 Transfer the embryo regions from Dispase solution into a large volume of cold L-15 medium.
2.5 Use tungsten needles to dissect the neural tissue away from other germ layers.
2.6 Sub-dissect the hypothalamus using morphological criteria to define its limits.
2.7 Transfer the dissected embryo to a clean 5cm square plastic plate and arrange it flat.
2.8 Slice the embryo into fragments using a tissue chopper.
2.9 Transfer anterior slices to L-15 medium and identify the hypothalamus-containing slice.
2.10 Transfer the hypothalamus slice to Dispase and isolate the neural tissue.
3. Embed tissue for three-dimensional explant culture.
3.1 Prepare the desired volume of 90% collagen and 10% 10× DMEM.
3.2 Pipette 20-25µL of collagen into a Nunc 4-well dish and allow to set at room temperature.
3.3 Transfer explants onto the collagen bed and overlay with 25µL of collagen.
3.4 Prepare the desired volume of 50% Matrigel and 50% explant medium.
3.5 Pipette 20-25µL of Matrigel into a Nunc 4-well dish and allow to set at 37°C.
3.6 Transfer explants onto the Matrigel bed and overlay with 25µL of Matrigel.

system_prompt: As an expert in biochemical and molecular functional analysis, specializing in hydrogenase activity and H2 production quantification, structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Ensure steps are imperative, consistent in tense, and logically linked. Exclude theoretical explanations or material lists.
instruction: Decompose the protocol into nested operational steps (2 ≤ main steps ≤ 10, substeps ≤ 15/main step, subsubsteps ≤ 15/substep). Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/parameter continuity across steps. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers. Avoid non-operational descriptions or assumptions.
input: To quantify hydrogenase activity and H2 production in recombinant E. coli. Available materials: LB broth, ampicillin, streptomycin, glucose, ferric ammonium citrate, MOPS buffer, L-cysteine, sodium fumarate, IPTG, NaCl solution, Pierce BCA Protein Assay kit, MV2+/Na2S2O4 solution, TCA, gas chromatograph. How to cultivate bacteria, harvest cells, and measure hydrogenase activity?
output: 1. Cultivation of Hydrogenase-Expressing Bacteria.
1.1. Utilize a recombinant E. coli strain expressing hydA, hydE, hydF, and hydG genes for hydrogenase expression.
1.2. Aerobic Pre-Culture.

1.2.1. Pre-culture the recombinant E. coli in a 500mL Erlenmeyer flask containing 200mL of LB broth supplemented with 100ug/mL ampicillin, 40ug/mL streptomycin, 0.5% (w/v) glucose, 250ug/mL ferric ammonium citrate, and 100mM MOPS/NaOH pH 7.4.
1.3. Anaerobic Incubation.
1.3.1. Transfer 200mL of the pre-cultured E. coli suspension into a 250mL centrifuge bottle inside an anaerobic glove box, adding 2mM L-cysteine, 20mM sodium fumarate, and 1mM IPTG.
1.3.2. Incubate in the glove box for 18h to express FeFe-hydrogenase.
2. Cell Harvesting and Preparation.
2.1. Transfer 200mL of the cell suspension to a centrifuge bottle with a silicone cap to maintain anaerobic conditions.
2.2. Centrifuge at 2000×g for 10min, discard the supernatant, and collect the cell pellet.
2.3. Wash the cell pellet once with 5mL of 0.9% NaCl solution, then centrifuge at 2000×g for 10min.
2.4. Resuspend the washed cell pellet in 5mL of 0.9% NaCl solution.
2.5. Standardize the protocol by measuring total protein content using a Pierce BCA Protein Assay kit to determine cell concentration.
3. Hydrogenase Activity Assay.
3.1. Degas all reagents with pure N2 for 5min and prepare them inside the anaerobic glove box.
3.2. Prepare the reaction mixture according to Table 1 and Figure 2B.
3.3. Purge each vial with pure N2 for 5min to remove contaminated gases.
3.4. Initiate the reaction by adding 0.2mL of 50mM MV2+/Na2S2O4 solution to the reaction vial.
3.5. Incubate in a shaking water bath at 100rpm and 37°C.
3.6. Terminate the reaction by adding 0.1mL of 100% TCA after 20min of incubation.
3.7. Sample 1mL of H2 from the headspace of the reaction vial using a gas-tight syringe and inject into a gas chromatograph for analysis.

system_prompt: As a Bioinformatics Methods expert specializing in phylogenetic inference of homologous/orthologous genes among distantly related plants, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step software/tool coordination while maintaining strict adherence to computational and biological specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure software/tool continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To identify homologous/orthologous genes among distantly related plants using sequence similarity-based searching and phylogenetic analysis. Available tools: Miniconda3, Diamond, MAFFT, TrimAL, IQ-TREE, InterProScan, TBtools, Jalview. How to install software, process genomic data, identify orthologs, and construct phylogenetic trees?
output: 1. Software Installation.
1.1. Miniconda3 Installation.
1.1.1. Download Miniconda3 using the command: wget https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/anaconda/miniconda/Miniconda3-py39_4.12.0-Linux-x86_64.sh.
1.1.2. Install Miniconda3 using the command: bash Miniconda3-py39_4.12.0-Linux-x86_64.sh.
1.2. Diamond Installation.
1.2.1. Download Diamond using the command: wget https://github.com/bbuchfink/diamond/releases/download/v2.1.7/diamond-linux64.tar.gz.
1.2.2. Extract Diamond using the command: tar -zxvf diamond-linux64.tar.gz.
1.2.3. Add the path of Diamond to the environment variable.
1.3. MAFFT Installation.
1.3.1. Install MAFFT using the command: conda install mafft.
1.4. TrimAL Installation.
1.4.1. Download TrimAL using the command: wget https://github.com/inab/trimal/archive/refs/tags/v1.4.1.tar.gz.
1.4.2. Extract TrimAL using the command: tar -zxvf trimal-1.4.1.tar.gz.
1.4.3. Compile TrimAL using the command: make.
1.4.4. Add the current directory to the environment variable.
1.5. IQ-TREE Installation.
1.5.1. Download IQ-TREE using the command: wget https://github.com/iqtree/iqtree2/releases/download/v2.2.2.6/iqtree-2.2.2.6-Linux.tar.gz.
1.5.2. Extract IQ-TREE using the command: tar -zxvf iqtree-2.2.2.6-Linux.tar.gz.
1.5.3. Add the ./iqtree-2.2.2.6-Linux/bin to the environment variable.
1.6. InterProScan Installation.
1.6.1. Follow the instructions on the InterProScan documentation website to download and install InterProScan.
1.7. TBtools Installation.
1.7.1. Download TBtools from https://github.com/CJ-Chen/TBtools/releases/download/1.123/TBtools_windows-x64_1_123.exe.
1.8. Jalview Installation.
1.8.1. Download Jalview from https://www.jalview.org/.
2. Genome and Transcriptome Download and Processing.
2.1. Plant Genomes Download.
2.1.1. Download protein sequences or coding sequences (CDS) and GFF annotation files for 39 streptophytes, 54 chlorophytes, 9 rhodophytes, and 1 glaucophyte.
2.2. Removing Redundant Transcripts and Short Genes.
2.2.1. Use TBtools to remove redundant transcripts and short genes based on the GFF annotation files.
2.2.2. Retain the longest transcript of each gene to remove redundancy resulting from alternative splicing variations.
2.2.3. Calculate protein sequences length of genes using TBtools and filter out sequences shorter than 50 amino acids.
3. Identifying Orthologous Genes within Large-Scale Genomic/Transcriptomic Data.
3.1. Identifying Candidate Homologs from Genomes.
3.1.1. Conduct similarity searches with relative stringency threshold (E value <1×10^-5) against the protein sequences of plant genomes using Diamond.
3.1.2. Create a database of protein sequences using Diamond.
3.2. Identifying Candidate Homologs from Transcriptomes.
3.2.1. Use a relatively relaxed threshold to search candidate homologs from plant transcriptomes (E value <1×10^-2) using Diamond.
3.3. Filtering Sequences with Blast-Hits.
3.3.1. Integrate candidate homologs from both genomes and transcriptomes into a single fasta file.
3.3.2. Use InterProScan to filter homologous sequences without a conserved functional domain: N-acetyltransferase (PF00583).
4. Orthologs Inference with Phylogenetic Analyses.
4.1. Alignment and Trimming of Homologous Sequences.
4.1.1. Align homologous sequences using MAFFT.
4.1.2. Trim the alignment using TrimAL with a relatively relaxed threshold (‘-gt=0.13’).
4.1.3. Manually inspect the sequence alignment using Jalview and exclude any sequences with error alignment.
4.2. Constructing a Phylogenetic Tree of Homologous Proteins.
4.2.1. Infer the maximum likelihood phylogenetic tree of homologous proteins using IQ-TREE 2.
4.2.2. Determine the best-fitting model using ModelFinder.
4.2.3. Evaluate branch supports using the ultrafast bootstrap (UFBoot) approach and SH approximate likelihood ratio test (SH-aLRT test) with 1,000 replicates.
4.3. Confirmation of Orthologous Sequences using Function Domains/Motifs.
4.3.1. Analyze conserved functional domains/motifs using MEME suite.
4.3.2. Map corresponding functional domains and motifs of each orthologous sequence to the phylogenetic tree using iTOL.
4.3.3. Check and highlight two conserved residues (L327 and E346 in AtHLS1) in the MSA.

system_prompt: As an expert in biochemical and molecular functional analysis, specializing in protein-lipid interaction studies, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To prepare phospholipid bilayers for studying protein-lipid interactions, particularly for membrane-bound proteins like MARCH5. Available materials: Egg PE, Heart CL, Egg PA, Egg PG, Egg PC, Brain PI(4)P, chloroform, LMNG, purified MARCH5, PVDF membrane, TBS, BSA, antibodies. How to prepare lipid bilayers and perform lipid-binding assays?
output: 1. Lipid Preparation.
1.1. Fill round-bottom glass tubes with argon gas.
1.2. Transfer 20uL of Egg PE, Heart CL, Egg PA, Egg PC, and Egg PC chloroform solutions and 50uL of Brain PI(4)P chloroform solution to a separate argon gas–filled round-bottom glass tube.
1.3. Dry the lipids under an argon stream and shake on a pulsing vortex mixer for 15min.
1.4. Re-suspend Dry Lipids.
1.4.1. Re-suspend dry lipids to 5uM under shaking, depending on their average molecular weight.
1.4.2. Lipid Re-suspension Volumes.
1.4.2.1. Egg PE (MW: 746 Da) in 54uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.4.2.2. Heart CL (MW: 1494 Da) in 27uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.4.2.3. Egg PA (MW: 711 Da) in 57uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.4.2.4. Egg PC (MW: 770 Da) in 52uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.4.2.5. Egg PG (MW: 782) in 51uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.4.2.6. Brain PI(4)P (MW: 974) in 10uL of 0.25% LMNG.
1.5. Add 1.8uL of the 5uM lipid solution to 50uL of 32uM purified MARCH5.
1.6. Incubate the lipid–protein solution on ice for 1h.
1.7. The protein is now considered ready for activity and/or stability measurements.
2. Lipid-Binding Assay.
2.1. Cut a rectangle (2cm×6cm) of the PVDF membrane.
2.2. Spot 1uL of the chloroform solutions of Egg PE, Heart CL, Egg PA, Egg PC, Egg PG, and Brain PI(4)P on the PVDF membrane.
2.3. Dry the spotted lipid for 1h at room temperature (RT) in a laminar flow hood.
2.4. Positive Controls.
2.4.1. Spot 1uL of Anti-rabbit IgG, HRP-linked antibody on the membrane lipid strip.
2.4.2. Spot 1uL of 0.35mg/mL target protein.
2.5. Dry positive controls for 15min.
2.6. Block the PVDF membrane with 30mL of TBS supplemented with 3% BSA overnight at 4°C with soft agitation on a plate shaker.
2.7. Remove the blocking solution.
2.8. Add 10mL of 1ug/mL of MARCH5 in TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG and 3% BSA to the PVDF membrane.
2.9. Incubate the PVDF membrane and MARCH5 for 4h at 4°C with soft agitation on a plate shaker.
2.10. Wash the PVDF membrane three times with 5mL of TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG for 5min at RT under soft agitation.
2.11. Add 5mL of Anti-MARCH5 antibody N-terminal in TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG and 3% BSA to the PVDF membrane.
2.12. Incubate anti-MARCH5 antibody N-terminal for 4h at 4°C.
2.13. Remove the antibody solution and rinse the PVDF with 5mL of TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG.
2.14. Add anti-rabbit IgG, HRP-linked Antibody in 5mL of TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG and 3% BSA to the PVDF membrane.
2.15. Wash again the membrane lipid strip three times in 5mL of TBS supplemented with 0.001% LMNG for 5 min at RT under soft agitation.
2.16. Prepare PierceTM ECL western blotting substrate, add onto the membrane lipid strip, and incubate for 1 min.
2.17. Measure chemiluminescence using the ChemiDocTM Touch Gel imaging system.

system_prompt: As an expert in microfluidic device fabrication and yeast strain library screening, demonstrate expertise in hierarchical protocol decomposition, parameter inheritance, and interdisciplinary reagent/instrument coordination while adhering to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the microfluidic platform protocol into a hierarchical format with multi-level steps. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure continuity of materials and instruments across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Steps should be numbered as [MainStep].[SubStep].[SubSubStep].
input: To create a high-throughput yeast strain library screening platform using a microfluidic device. Available materials: PDMS, SU-8 photoresist, Singer ROTOR, oxygen plasma system. How to fabricate and integrate the microfluidic device components?
output: 1. Photolithography for Wafer Fabrication.
1.1. Device Layout and Design.
1.1.1. Refer to Figure 1 for device layout details.
1.2. Wafer Fabrication.
1.2.1. Fabricate silicon wafer using standard photolithography techniques (Ferry et al., 2011).
1.3. Spin Protocols.
1.3.1. Use standard spin protocols from SU-8 manufacturer.
1.3.2. Spin all layers at specified speeds for 30s after a 10s photoresist spreading step.
1.4. Layer Fabrication.
1.4.1. Conduit Layer: Fabricate using 2002 SU-8 photoresist at 1,000 rpm, resulting in 2.4μm height.
1.4.2. Spotting Region Layer: Fabricate using 2005 SU-8 photoresist at 2,600 rpm, resulting in 4.8–5μm height.
1.4.3. HD Biopixel Layer: Fabricate using 2007 SU-8 photoresist at 1,000 rpm, resulting in 12μm height.
1.4.4. Minor Channel Layer: Fabricate using 2075 SU-8 photoresist at 4,000 rpm, resulting in 60–65μm height.
1.4.5. Major Channel Layer: Fabricate using 2075 SU-8 photoresist at 2,400 rpm with a 1h edge bead removal step at 40°C, resulting in 145–170μm height.
2. Soft Lithography for PDMS Devices.
2.1. PDMS Preparation.
2.1.1. Dispense 70g of Dow Corning Sylgard 184 elastomer base and mix with 7g of curing agent.
2.1.2. Mix thoroughly for 3–5min using a glass stir rod.
2.2. Bubble Removal.
2.2.1. Place PDMS mixture in a vacuum desiccator.
2.2.2. Periodically vent the chamber to remove bubbles.
2.3. PDMS Pouring.
2.3.1. Cut 16×16 inch aluminum foil and fold to 8×8 inch.
2.3.2. Place a 5×5×0.25 inch glass plate in the center and fold foil edges to form a bowl.
2.4. PDMS Curing.
2.4.1. Pour bubble-free PDMS onto the photopatterned wafer.
2.4.2. Degas the PDMS in a vacuum desiccator.
2.4.3. Remove after 30min–1h when all bubbles are gone.
2.5. PDMS Processing.
2.5.1. Remove wafer from vacuum chamber.
2.5.2. Re-center wafer if needed using pipette tips.
2.5.3. Push down on wafer sides to ensure even contact and remove excess PDMS.
2.6. Baking.
2.6.1. Bake wafer stack at 95°C for 1h.
2.6.2. Note PDMS shrinkage at this temperature.
2.7. PDMS Removal.
2.7.1. Remove aluminum foil and excess PDMS with a razor blade.
2.7.2. Slide razor blade between wafer and glass plate to separate.
2.8. PDMS Cutting.
2.8.1. Remove excess PDMS from wafer bottom.
2.8.2. Peel PDMS from wafer in major channel direction.
2.9. PDMS Cleaning.
2.9.1. Place PDMS on a cutting mat feature-side up.
2.9.2. Cut out each PDMS device.
2.9.3. Punch inlet and outlet channels with 0.5mm biopsy puncher.
2.10. PDMS Storage.
2.10.1. Rinse devices with 70% ethanol.
2.10.2. Blow dry with compressed air or nitrogen.
2.10.3. Clean devices with scotch tape.
3. Glass Slide Cleaning.
3.1. Sonication.
3.1.1. Sonicate slides in 2% Helmanex III solution for 30min at 40°C.
3.2. Rinsing.
3.2.1. Rinse slides with deionized water while rubbing with a nitrile glove.
3.3. Drying.
3.3.1. Dry slides with pressurized nitrogen until no streaks remain.
4. Cell Preparation and Device Loading.
4.1. Agar Dispensing.
4.1.1. Dispense 42mL of SC agar into Singer Plus Plates.
4.2. Plate Drying.
4.2.1. Allow plates to dry on benchtop for 48h, covered with Parafilm, then store at 4°C.
4.3. Cell Growth.
4.3.1. Grow yTRAP library strains in 96-well plates with YPD media overnight at 30°C.
4.4. Spotting.
4.4.1. Use Singer ROTOR to spot liquid plate onto SC agar Plus Plate with default pinning settings.
4.5. Arraying.
4.5.1. Use Singer ROTOR to combine four 1536-density source plates onto one 6144-density plate using 1:4 Array program and settings from Table 1.
4.6. Tool Preparation.
4.6.1. Replicate four 1536-density source plates onto four 1536-density SC agar plates using Singer ROTOR Replicate program.
4.6.2. Combine onto one 6144-density plate using 1:4 Array program and Table 1 settings.
4.7. PDMS Alignment.
4.7.1. Align acrylic tool on mask holder with alignment cells up.
4.7.2. Focus on device cells with optics.
4.7.3. Place PDMS device on alignment cells, feature-side up, centering spotting regions over cells.
4.8. Oxygen Plasma Exposure.
4.8.1. Expose glass slide and PDMS acrylic stack to 30W oxygen plasma for 30s.
4.8.2. Clean with compressed nitrogen.
4.9. Cell Spotting.
4.9.1. Spot cells from 6144-density plate onto oxygen plasma–exposed PDMS acrylic stack using Singer ROTOR and Table 1 parameters.
4.10. Device Bonding.
4.10.1. Peel spotted PDMS from acrylic and place face down on oxygen plasma–exposed glass slide.
4.10.2. Tap PDMS top gently to ensure bonding.
4.11. Experiment Setup.
4.11.1. Place chip in vacuum desiccator for 20min.
4.11.2. Wet chip by adding ≥20μL of microfluidic media to inlet and outlet ports.

system_prompt: As an Immunological Techniques expert specializing in cancer cell reprogramming and antigen-presenting cell generation, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To reprogram cancer cells into tumor-APCs using cDC1 transcription factors, enhancing antigen presentation and T-cell engagement. Available materials: cancer cell cultures, culture media, viral particles, polybrene solution, MACS buffer, antibodies, flow cytometer. How to prepare, reprogram, purify, and evaluate tumor-APCs?
output: 1. Preparing Cancer Cell Cultures for Reprogramming.
1.1. Thaw and culture cancer cells in recommended media under standard conditions (37°C, 5% CO2).
1.2. Monitor cell division and morphology using an inverted light microscope.
1.3. Counting and Expanding Cells.
1.3.1. Use a hemocytometer to count cells.
1.3.2. For adherent cells, plate 1×10^6 live cells per 100mm tissue culture plate.
1.3.3. For non-adherent cells, skip to step B2.
2. Tumor-APC Reprogramming.
2.1. Pre-warm cell culture media for 5min at 37°C.
2.2. Cancer Cell Transduction.
2.2.1. Resuspend 4×10^4 viral particles per cell in 10mL.
2.2.2. Add 10mL of polybrene solution to 10mL of transduction media (final concentration: 8mg/mL).
2.2.3. Incubate at 37°C, 5% CO2 for 24h in transduction media.
2.3. Changing Media of Transduced Cells.
2.3.1. For adherent cultures, aspirate supernatant and carefully add media on top of the cells.
2.3.2. For non-adherent cells, transfer cell suspension to a 50mL centrifuge tube, centrifuge, and resuspend cells in adequate media volume.
2.4. Observing Cells and Passaging.
2.4.1. At day 3, observe cells under an inverted light microscope.
2.4.2. If transduced cancer cells in a 100mm tissue culture plate reach 80% confluency at day 3, passage cells.
2.4.3. For non-adherent cells, transfer cell suspension to a 50mL centrifuge tube, count cells, and resuspend in adequate volume of fresh media.
2.5. Changing Media and Evaluating Reprogramming.
2.5.1. Change media every 2–3 days according to media color and cell confluency.
2.5.2. Assess tumor-APC emergence at days 5, 8, and 9 post-transduction by flow cytometric analysis.
3. Purifying Tumor-APCs for Functional Assays by MACS-Enrichment.
3.1. At day 9 of reprogramming, detach cells and resuspend them in cold MACS buffer.
3.2. Count cells using a hemocytometer and calculate total cell number.
3.3. Performing MACS-Enrichment.
3.3.1. Centrifuge cell suspension and resuspend cells in MACS buffer.
3.3.2. Add rat serum and biotin-labeled anti-CD45 and anti-MHC-II to the cell suspension.
3.3.3. Incubate on ice and then wash cells with cold MACS buffer.
3.4. Eluting and Resuspending Cells.
3.4.1. Add anti-biotin microbeads to the cell suspension and incubate on ice.
3.4.2. Prepare magnetic MACS MultiStand and columns, and equilibrate columns with cold MACS buffer.
3.4.3. Transfer cell suspension onto the column and wash with MACS buffer.
3.5. Evaluating MACS-Enrichment Efficiency.
3.5.1. Centrifuge the eluted cell suspension and resuspend the cell pellet in media.
3.5.2. Count cells using a hemocytometer and save a portion of the cell suspension for flow cytometric analysis.
4. Evaluating Exogenous Antigen Presentation to Naïve Murine CD4+ T Cells.
4.1. Thaw BM-DCs and resuspend them in pre-warmed complete RPMI.
4.2. Prepare tumor-APCs, eGFP-transduced cancer cells, and BM-DCs for antigen presentation assays.
4.3. Setting Up Antigen Presentation Assays.
4.3.1. Prepare a tissue-culture-treated 96-well U-shaped bottom plate with media and APCs.
4.3.2. Prepare Naïve CD4+ T cells and add them to the wells with APCs.
4.3.3. Incubate plates at 37°C, 5% CO2 for four full days.
4.4. Evaluating T Cell Activation and Proliferation.
4.4.1. Prepare antibody staining solution and add fixable viability dye.
4.4.2. Centrifuge plates and add antibody-viability dye staining solution.
4.4.3. Incubate plates for 30min at 4°C and then resuspend cell pellets in cold MACS buffer.

system_prompt: As a Neuroscience Methods expert specializing in visual associative learning in Drosophila, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/instrument continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To study visual associative learning in freely walking fruit flies at an individual level using a novel behavioral paradigm. Available materials: visual diffuser paper, acrylic cylinder, black squares, Buritrack software, Buridan chamber, ethanol 70%, filter paper, glucose solution, Evian water, CO2 pistol, CO2-dispensing porous pad, scissors, microscope, food, starvation vials, Buridan fluorescent lights. How to prepare flies, set up the behavioral arena, run training and testing sessions?
output: 1. Prepare Flies for Behavioral Recording.
1.1. Raise flies at 12:12 h light/dark cycle, 60% humidity, and 25°C.
1.2. Dispose of hatched flies if their age is not controlled.
1.3. Collect all newly hatched flies into a new experimental vial (no more than 20 flies per vial).
1.4. Collect 5-day-old flies (at least 60 flies: 30 for control group and 30 for trained group) and transfer them to a new vial with fresh food.
1.5. Anesthetize the flies by holding the vial upside down and inserting the CO2 pistol.
1.6. Transfer the flies to a CO2-dispensing porous pad.
1.7. Clip both wings using scissors under the microscope.
1.8. Save each fly in individual vials with food at 25°C.
1.9. Split and store them in two different racks—one for the control group (CT) and one for the trained group (TR).
1.10. Seven-day-old flies are used for the experiment.
1.11. Twenty-one hours before running the experiment, place each fly in a starving vial containing a piece of filter paper watered with Evian water.
2. Prepare Behavioral Arena for Learning Experiment.
2.1. Place the visual diffuser paper on the inside of the acrylic cylinder.
2.2. Tape the black squares with scotch tape.
2.3. Open the Buritrack software and place the visual sets in the top and bottom part of the image captured by the webcam.
2.4. Add distilled water to the Buritrack chamber.
2.5. Darken the room and switch on the Buridan fluorescent lights.
2.6. Clean the platform with ethanol 70%.
2.7. Place the round filter paper on the platform.
2.8. Add two drops of glucose solution and two drops of Evian water to the respective visual stimuli for the trained group.
2.9. Add two drops of water next to each stimulus for the control group.
3. Run the Training Session.
3.1. Set the temperature of the platform to 25°C.
3.2. Press the Button New Tracking and adjust all the parameters in the Tracking dialog.
3.3. Generate a folder named 'Training' to save your recording.
3.4. Set the size of the arena.
3.5. Gently place the fly on the platform and activate tracking in Buritrack.
3.6. If the fly jumps off of the platform, put it back on the platform and click Activate Tracking again.
3.7. After 3 min, gently remove the fly from the platform and place it back in their starving vial.
3.8. Clean the platform with 70% ethanol and prepare a new filter paper for the next fly.
4. Run the Testing Session.
4.1. Right after finishing the training session, clean the platform with abundant water and 70% ethanol.
4.2. Two hours after finishing the training session, place a clean filter paper on the platform.
4.3. Place the fly to record the testing session.
4.4. Generate a folder named 'Testing' to save your recording.
4.5. Set the size of the arena.
4.6. Activate tracking in Buritrack to record walking behavior.
4.7. After running the recording, remove the filter paper and clean the platform with 70% ethanol.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology expert specializing in human induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) differentiation into chondrocytes, structure the protocol into hierarchical steps with parameter inheritance and maintain continuity of materials and equipment across steps.
instruction: Develop a hierarchical protocol for differentiating human iPSCs into chondrocytes. Include steps for thawing, passage, derivation of mesenchymal progenitors, cryopreservation, surface antigen analysis, differentiation, histological assessment, and qPCR. Use imperative verbs and maintain consistent tense. Exclude theoretical explanations.
input: To differentiate human iPSCs into functional chondrocytes for skeletal research and regenerative medicine. Available materials: mTeSR Plus medium, ReLeSR, Geltrex, Mesenchymal Stem Cell (MSC) growth medium, Trypsin-EDTA, TRIzol, SYBR Green master mix. How to perform iPSC thawing, passage, differentiation, and analysis?
output: 1. Thawing and Recovering Human iPSCs.
1.1. Preparation.
1.1.1. Pre-warm mTeSR Plus medium to room temperature.
1.1.2. Prepare Geltrex-coated 6-well plates.
1.2. Thawing.
1.2.1. Retrieve cryogenic vial and place in 37°C water bath.
1.2.2. Thaw cells by swirling.
1.2.3. Transfer to laminar hood.
1.3. Cell Suspension and Centrifugation.
1.3.1. Transfer cell suspension to Falcon tube with F12 medium.
1.3.2. Rinse vial with F12 medium.
1.3.3. Centrifuge at 300×g for 5min.
1.4. Cell Resuspension and Plating.
1.4.1. Resuspend pellet in mTeSR Plus medium.
1.4.2. Add ROCK inhibitor.
1.4.3. Prepare Geltrex-coated plate.
1.4.4. Plate iPSC suspension.
1.5. Incubation and Medium Change.
1.5.1. Tilt plate to disperse cells.
1.5.2. Incubate overnight.
1.5.3. Replace medium with fresh mTeSR Plus.
2. Passage iPSCs using ReLeSR method.
2.1. Preparation.
2.1.1. Coat new 6-well plates with Geltrex.
2.1.2. Pre-warm mTeSR Plus medium.
2.2. Cell Detachment and Collection.
2.2.1. Aspirate medium and wash with DPBS.
2.2.2. Add ReLeSR to wells.
2.2.3. Aspirate ReLeSR solution.
2.3. Cell Resuspension and Plating.
2.3.1. Add mTeSR Plus medium to wells.
2.3.2. Monitor cell dissociation.
2.3.3. Pipette cell mixtures to disperse colonies.
2.4. Cell Collection and Centrifugation.
2.4.1. Collect cell aggregates into tube.
2.4.2. Centrifuge at 300×g for 5min.
2.4.3. Add mTeSR Plus medium.
2.5. Cell Plating and Incubation.
2.5.1. Prepare Geltrex-coated plate.
2.5.2. Plate cell suspension.
3. Derivation of Mesenchymal Progenitors from iPSCs.
3.1. Preparation.
3.1.1. Coat 6-well plates with 0.1% gelatin.
3.1.2. Wash plates with PBS.
3.2. Cell Detachment and Collection.
3.2.1. Remove mTeSR Plus medium and wash with PBS.
3.2.2. Apply ReLeSR to wells.
3.2.3. Aspirate ReLeSR solution.
3.3. Cell Resuspension and Plating.
3.3.1. Add mTeSR Plus medium to wells.
3.3.2. Remove colonies with cell lifter.
3.3.3. Pipette cell mixtures to break colonies.
3.4. Cell Collection and Centrifugation.
3.4.1. Centrifuge at 300×g for 5min.
3.4.2. Wash with PBS and add MSC medium.
3.5. Cell Plating and Incubation.
3.5.1. Plate iPSCs onto gelatin-coated plates.
3.5.2. Employ 1:1 or 1:2 split ratio.
4. Cryopreserving iPSC-MSCs.
4.1. Preparation.
4.1.1. Prepare 2×MSC freezing medium on ice.
4.2. Cell Detachment and Collection.
4.2.1. Obtain single cell suspension using Trypsin-EDTA.
4.2.2. Resuspend cells in MSC medium.
4.3. Cell Counting and Freezing.
4.3.1. Count cells using hemocytometer.
4.3.2. Adjust density to 2×10¶6 cells/mL.
4.3.3. Add freezing medium and aliquot into cryogenic vials.
5. MSC Surface Antigens Analysis by Flow Cytometry.
5.1. Preparation.
5.1.1. Prepare single-cell suspension.
5.2. Cell Staining.
5.2.1. Resuspend cells in 1% FBS in DPBS.
