5.2.2. Count cells and adjust density to 2×10¶6 cells/mL.
5.2.3. Transfer 2×10·5 cells into tubes.
5.3. Flow Cytometry Analysis.
5.3.1. Add MSC antibodies and mix.
5.3.2. Incubate for 30min at room temperature.
5.3.3. Wash cells with 1% FBS in DPBS.
6. Differentiation of iPSC-MSCs into Chondrocytes.
6.1. Micromass Method.
6.1.1. Expand iMSCs in 10cm dish.
6.1.2. Wash cells with PBS.
6.1.3. Apply Trypsin-EDTA solution.
6.2. Pellet Formation Method.
6.2.1. Harvest iMSCs using Trypsin-EDTA.
6.2.2. Resuspend in MSC growth medium.
6.2.3. Count viable cells using Trypan Blue.
7. Histological Assessment of Chondrogenic Matrix Production.
7.1. Preparation.
7.1.1. Harvest cell pellets and wash with PBS.
7.1.2. Fix pellets in formalin for 15min.
7.2. Dehydration and Embedding.
7.2.1. Dehydrate pellets through ethanol and xylene.
7.2.2. Embed in low-melt paraffin.
7.3. Sectioning and Staining.
7.3.1. Section paraffin-embedded pellets at 5-7um.
7.3.2. De-paraffinize and rehydrate sections.
7.3.3. Detect sulfated proteoglycans with acetic acid.
8. Quantitative PCR Analyses of Cartilage Genes.
8.1. RNA Extraction.
8.1.1. Combine pellets with TRIzol and transfer to tubes.
8.1.2. Pass pellets through 26·1/2-gauge needle.
8.2. cDNA Synthesis and Real-time PCR.
8.2.1. Add chloroform, vortex, and incubate for 5min.
8.2.2. Centrifuge at 12×100·g for 15min.
8.2.3. Transfer RNA layers to new tubes.

system_prompt: As an expert in Neuroscience Methods, specializing in the generation of vascularized cerebral organoids, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent coordination. Strictly adhere to experimental specifications and exclude theoretical explanations.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To generate vascularized cerebral organoids incorporating brain-resident microglia and robust vascular networks. Available materials: H9 human embryonic stem cells, Matrigel, mTeSR medium, Y27632, Accutase, Lipidure, growth factor-reduced Matrigel. How to culture cells, induce organoids, and fuse血管organoids with neuroepithelial tissues?
output: 1. H9-EGFP and H9-ES Cell Culture.
1.1 Confirm identity of H9 cell line via short tandem repeat (STR) profiling and mycoplasma testing.
1.2 Generate H9-EGFP cell line by CRISPR/Cas9-mediated integration of CAG-EGFP into ROSAβgeo26 locus.
1.3 Note: Source H9 cells from WiCell Research Institute or alternative suppliers.
2. Coating 6-Well Plates with Matrigel.
2.1 Thaw Matrigel overnight in fridge and place on ice to prevent gelation.
2.2 Dilute Matrigel stock with cold DMEM/F12 until evenly dispersed.
2.3 Add 1 mL Matrigel per well, distribute evenly, and incubate for 1 hour.
3. Cell Thawing.
3.1 Add 10 μM Y27632 to ESC medium and warm to 37°C for 30 minutes.
3.2 Thaw cells in 37°C water bath and transfer to fresh mTeSR medium.
3.3 Centrifuge at 200 × g for 2 minutes, resuspend in mTeSR with Y27632.
4. Blood Vessel Organoid (VOr) Generation.
4.1 Blood Vessel Organoid Aggregation, Day 0.
4.1.1 Culture H9-EGFP cells and detach with Accutase.
4.1.2 Collect medium into 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 200 × g for 2 minutes.
4.1.3 Resuspend cells in mTeSR with Y27632 and count viable cells.
4.2 Making Embryoid Bodies (EBs).
4.2.1 Prepare 0.5% Lipidure solution and add 20 μL to each well of V-bottom 96-well plate.
4.2.2 Dilute cells to 7,000-9,000 cells/150 μL and plate in Lipidure-coated wells.
4.2.3 Culture for 48 hours to induce EB formation.
4.3 Organoid Induction, Days 2-10.
4.3.1 Replace medium with mesoderm induction medium on day 2 and culture for 48 hours.
4.3.2 Replace medium with endothelial induction medium on day 4 and culture for 72 hours.
4.3.3 Replace medium with endothelial maturation medium on days 7-11 and culture for 48 hours.
4.4 Embedding Organoids in Matrigel, Day 12.
4.4.1 Prepare dimpled Parafilm and sterilize via UV for over 1 hour.
4.4.2 Transfer each vessel organoid to small dimple in Parafilm.
4.4.3 Add 10 μL Matrigel and adjust organoid position to center.
4.5 Vessel Organoid Maturation, Days 16-40.
4.5.1 Replace expansion medium with maturation medium on day 16 and move to shaker.
4.5.2 Half-change medium every 2-3 days.
5. Brain Organoid Generation.
5.1 Making EBs, Day 0.
5.1.1 Culture H9 cells and detach with Accutase.
5.1.2 Collect medium into 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 200 × g for 2 minutes.
5.1.3 Resuspend cells in mTeSR with Y27632 and count viable cells.
5.2 Neuroepithelium Induction, Days 2-10.
5.2.1 Replace medium with ectoderm induction medium on day 2 and culture for 48 hours.
5.2.2 Half-change medium on day 4 and continue for 48 hours.
5.2.3 Replace medium with neuroepithelium induction medium on day 6 and culture for 48 hours.
5.3 Embedding Neuroepithelial Tissues in Matrigel, Day 12.
5.3.1 Prepare dimpled Parafilm and sterilize via UV for over 1 hour.
5.3.2 Transfer each neuroepithelial tissue to small dimple in Parafilm.
5.3.3 Add 10 μL Matrigel and adjust tissue position to center.
5.4 Brain Organoid Maturation, Days 16-40.
5.4.1 Replace induction medium with maturation medium on day 16 and move to shaker.
5.4.2 Half-change medium every 2-3 days.
6. Vascularized Brain Organoid Generation.
6.1 Generate vessel organoids as per section B (days 0-10).
6.2 Generate neuroepithelial tissues as per section C (days 0-10).
6.3 Fusion of Vessel and Brain Organoids.
6.3.1 Prepare vessel organoids and neuroepithelial tissues for fusion.
6.3.2 Transfer two vessel organoids and one neuroepithelial tissue to each dimple.
6.3.3 Add 25 μL Matrigel and align tissues with neural tissue in center.
6.4 Culture of Fusion Tissues.
6.4.1 Place droplets in incubator to polymerize Matrigel for over 40 minutes.
6.4.2 Detach solidified tissues and culture in expansion medium for 4 days.
6.4.3 Replace medium with maturation medium on day 16 and move to shaker.

system_prompt: As an expert in microbiology protocols, specializing in bacterial biofilm assessment and characterization, particularly in the presence of inhibitory compounds, with a focus on Campylobacter jejuni.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical steps with parameter inheritance, using imperative verbs and maintaining tense consistency. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To assess and characterize bacterial biofilm formation in the presence of inhibitory compounds, particularly focusing on Campylobacter jejuni. Available materials: MHA media, MHB, crystal violet solution, MBDS solution, spectrophotometer, 24-well microplates, P. aeruginosa, DAPI, CLSM, and relevant antibiotics. How to perform biofilm inhibition and dispersal assays, including single-species, dual-species, and multi-species assays, and assess biofilm architecture using confocal microscopy?
output: 1. Biofilm Formation Inhibition Assay.
1.1. Prepare the bacterial suspension and dispense it into a 24-well microplate.
1.2. Dispense different concentrations of the tested compound in desired increments into the microplate.
1.3. Incubate the microplate to generate the biofilm inside the wells.
1.4. After incubation, wash the wells, allow them to dry, and stain with crystal violet solution.
1.5. Wash to remove excess dye and add MBDS solution to dissolve the stained biofilm.
1.6. Read absorbance of the de-stained MBDS solution on a spectrophotometer.
2. Single-Species Assay.
2.1. Recovery and Preparation of Bacterial Cells.
2.1.1. Recover C. jejuni NCTC 11168-O from -80°C storage, plate on MHA media with antibiotics, and incubate microaerobically at 42°C overnight.
2.1.2. Harvest cells into 1 mL MHB and transfer 100-200 µL into 15 mL MHB.
2.2. Incubation and Preparation of Bacterial Suspension.
2.2.1. Incubate microaerobically at 42°C and 125 rpm for 18-20 hours.
2.2.2. Dilute culture to achieve OD_600 of 0.05.
2.3. Dispensing Bacterial Suspension and Testing Compound.
2.3.1. Dispense 2 mL diluted suspension into each well.
2.3.2. Add chosen compound concentrations to the wells.
2.4. Incubation and Quantification of Biofilm Formation.
2.4.1. Cover plates and incubate for 24 hours.
2.4.2. Quantify biofilm following 'Assessment of biofilm formation'.
3. Dual/Multiple Species Assay.
3.1. Preparation of Mixed Bacterial Culture.
3.1.1. Grow P. aeruginosa aerobically in MHB overnight.
3.1.2. Adjust cell density to OD_600 of 0.1.
3.2. Incubation and Preparation of Mixed Suspension.
3.2.1. Use a 1:1 ratio of cell suspensions.
3.2.2. Repeat steps A4-A6.
4. Biofilm Dispersal Assay.
4.1. Preparation of Bacterial Suspension and Dispensing.
4.1.1. Prepare suspension and dispense into 24-well plates.
4.1.2. Incubate to generate biofilm.
4.2. Incubation and Testing of Compound.
4.2.1. Remove media, add 500 µL PBS with compound.
4.2.2. Incubate for 24 hours.
5. Assessment of Biofilm Formation.
5.1. Removal of Media and Rinsing.
5.1.1. Remove media and rinse with distilled water.
5.1.2. Dry plates by tapping.
5.2. Staining and Quantification.
5.2.1. Add 300 µL 0.1% crystal violet.
5.2.2. Add 500 µL MBDS and incubate for 10 minutes.
5.3. Measurement and Calculation.
5.3.1. Transfer solution to 96-well plate.
5.3.2. Quantify OD at 570-600 nm and calculate average.
6. CLSM Microscopy.
6.1. Preparation of Cells and Coverslips.
6.1.1. Prepare cells as described in steps A1-A3.
6.1.2. Place coverslips in 6-well plate.
6.2. Incubation and Fixation of Cells.
6.2.1. Dispense 2 mL suspension into wells.
6.2.2. Incubate for 24-72 hours.
6.3. Staining and Mounting.
6.3.1. Fix with 5% formaldehyde for 1 hour.
6.3.2. Stain with DAPI for DNA labeling.

system_prompt: As a Bioimaging Technologies expert specializing in chromatin structure and dynamics visualization using conventional and super-resolution PALM imaging, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To study chromatin structure and dynamics in live mammalian cells using correlative conventional and super-resolution PALM imaging. Available materials: GIST-T1 cells, Fluorobrite media, Opti-MEM, Lipofectamine 3000, p300 reagent, telomere 2xMS2 gRNA plasmid, MCP-HaloTag plasmid, dCas9-GFP plasmid, PA-JF646 dye, TetraSpeck microspheres, 8-well plates, and fluorescence microscopy equipment. How to culture, transfect cells, calibrate, and image chromatin structures?
output: 1. Cell Culture, Seeding, and Plasmid Transfections.
1.1. Seed GIST-T1 cells in 5mL of Fluorobrite media at a density of 33% (~400,000–600,000 cells) in a T25 tissue culture flask.
1.2. Culture cells for 1-2 days up to a density of 75%-80% in a humidified incubator at 37°C and 5% CO2.
1.3. Cell Splitting.
1.3.1. Aspirate media from the flask in a cell culture hood and wash cells with 37°C PBS twice.
1.3.2. Remove PBS and add 0.5 mL of phenol-red free trypsin EDTA to cover the entire flask surface.
1.3.3. Place flask in incubator for 2-3 min to allow cells to lift.
1.3.4. Verify cells have lifted.
1.4. Cell Neutralization and Seeding.
1.4.1. Add 2mL of Fluorobrite media to trypsinized cells to neutralize trypsin and seed cells at mentioned density with 5mL of Fluorobrite media.
1.4.2. Seed 50 μL of trypsinized cells in 8-well plates at a density of 50,000 cells/mL two days prior to imaging.
1.5. Plasmid Transfection.

1.5.1. Mix 200ng of telomere 2xMS2 gRNA plasmid, 50ng of MCP-HaloTag, and 50ng of dCas9-GFP plasmids with 10 μL of Opti-MEM, 1 μL of Lipofectamine 3000, and 0.5 μL of p300 reagent in a 1.7mL Eppendorf tube.
1.5.2. Incubate DNA/lipid mixture for 15min at room temperature.
1.5.3. Aspirate media from GIST-T1 cells and wash twice with 300 μL of 37°C Fluorobrite media.
1.5.4. Add 100 μL of Fluorobrite media with 4 mM L-Glutamine, 1% FBS, 1% penicillin/streptomycin, and 200 μL of Opti-MEM.
1.5.5. Incubate cells for 15min at 37°C and 5% CO2.
1.5.6. Remove cells from incubator, add DNA/lipid mixture dropwise to cells in each well.
1.6. Cell Incubation and Washing.
1.6.1. Place wells with transfecting cells in incubator for 15-17h.
1.6.2. Remove media and wash cells twice with serum-diluted Fluorobrite media.
1.7. Cell Washing and Incubation.
1.7.1. Wash cells three times with Fluorobrite media and incubate at 37°C and 5% CO2 for 30min.
1.7.2. Repeat washing three additional times prior to imaging to remove unbound PA-JF646 dye.
2. Calibration and Imaging Experiments.
2.1. Microsphere Calibration.
2.1.1. Mount microscope cover glass or 8-well plate with 10 μL of TetraSpeck microspheres diluted 1:100 in DI water.
2.1.2. Excite microspheres with 640 and 488 nm excitation at 1.75 mW power.
2.1.3. Record a 100-frame movie with 10 sparsely distributed microspheres over the field of view.
2.1.4. Sample entire field of view by moving microspheres and repeat steps B2 and B3 at least five times.
2.2. Cell Imaging.
2.2.1. Remove microsphere sample and mount 8-well plate with transfected cells.
2.2.2. Ensure stage is heated to 37°C and CO2 reads 5%.
2.2.3. Set up 10-frame laser shutter sequence at 20 Hz: 488 nm GFP, brightfield LED, 405 nm photoactivation, and frames 3–10 with 640 nm PALM imaging.
2.3. Image Acquisition.
2.3.1. Set 488 nm laser power to 1.75 mW and 640 nm to 17.5 mW.
2.3.2. Use 488 nm laser to identify cells with telomere puncta in nucleus.
2.3.3. Minimize 488 nm exposure to reduce bleaching.
2.3.4. Image telomere puncta conventionally for at least 200 frames at 20 Hz.
2.4. Single Molecule Imaging.
2.4.1. Begin 10-frame shutter and acquisition sequence after identifying telomere puncta.
2.4.2. Start with 1 μW 405 nm laser power and increase by 5-10 μW every 1,000 frames to 250 μW.
2.4.3. Record data for 15,000–30,000 frames, stopping when cells show morphology changes.
2.5. Data Acquisition and Analysis.
2.5.1. Repeat steps B5–B9 for more statistics.
2.5.2. Typically, 10 cells are considered satisfactory.

system_prompt: As an expert in cell biology protocols, specializing in microtubule organization and mitotic spindle analysis, your task is to decompose the provided protocol into a multi-level hierarchical structure. Ensure that steps are recorded in imperative verb form, parameters are inherited appropriately, and reagent/instrument continuity is maintained across steps.
instruction:
Construct a hierarchical protocol with the following criteria: 
1. Use imperative verbs for each step.
2. Ensure parameters are inherited from prior steps.
3. Maintain reagent and instrument continuity.
4. Limit each step to 50 words.
5. Exclude theoretical explanations.
6. Number steps as [MainStep].[SubStep].[SubSubStep].
input: To study microtubule organization in mitotic spindles using cryo-immobilization, fluorescence microscopy, and electron tomography. Available materials: cryotubes with cells, DMEM-WT medium, 3D-printed chambers, sapphire discs, poly-L-lysine, fibronectin, DMEM high-pressure freezing solution, methylene blue, osmium tetroxide, uranyl acetate, Epon/Araldite resin, ultramicrotome, TEM. What is the protocol for 3D reconstruction of mitotic spindles?
output: 1. Cell Culture Preparation.
1.1 Thaw cryotube with cells in warm water bath.
1.2 Add cells to T75 flask with 10mL pre-warmed DMEM-WT medium.
1.3 Incubate cells at 37°C with 5% CO2 for one day.
1.4 Replace medium with fresh pre-warmed DMEM-WT next day.
1.5 Passage cells 2-3 times for healthy culture.
1.6 Ensure 70% confluency prior to experiment.
2. 3D-Printed Chambers Preparation.
2.1 Design and print chambers for 3mm diameter sapphire discs.
2.2 Clean chambers with ethanol; store at 37°C with 5% CO2.
3. Sapphire Discs Preparation.
3.1 Clean discs in acetone; wash in ethanol and ddH2O.
3.2 Coat discs with poly-L-lysine and fibronectin.
3.3 Air dry discs; re-coat with poly-L-lysine and fibronectin.
4. Mitotic Shake-Off.
4.1 Warm medium to 37°C; store in incubator.
4.2 Move flasks to incubator near high-pressure freezer.
4.3 Synchronize cells by vigorous shaking.
4.4 Replace medium with fresh pre-warmed medium.
5. Sandwich Assembly.
5.1 Assemble sandwich as in Figure 2D-2I.
5.2 Place aluminum planchette in holder; fill cavity with 1μL DMEM freezing solution.
5.3 Dip sapphire disc in DMEM solution; place on aluminum carrier.
6. High-Pressure Freezing.
6.1 Close sample holder; freeze using machine.
6.2 Retrieve sandwich under liquid nitrogen.
7. Freeze-Substitution and Embedding.
7.1 Prepare methylene blue in acetone.
7.2 Add 1% osmium tetroxide and 0.1% uranyl acetate.
7.3 Perform freeze-substitution in automated machine.
7.4 Wash samples in acetone; arrange discs in Petri dish.
7.5 Infiltrate with Epon/Araldite at increasing concentrations.
7.6 Cut檙櫼 open; remove resin around sapphire discs.
7.7 Submerge resin block in liquid nitrogen for a few seconds.
8. Pre-Screening and Serial-Sectioning.
8.1 Screen resin block for rounded mitotic cells.
8.2 Image area of interest using microscope or smartphone.
8.3 Trim resin block surface for sectioning.
8.4 Cut 300nm sections at 1.6mm/s with ultramicrotome.
8.5 Collect sections on Formvar-coated copper grids.
9. Post-Staining and Imaging.
9.1 Post-stain sections with uranyl acetate and lead citrate.
9.2 Image sections using TEM.
9.3 Add fiducial markers with colloidal gold solution.
10. Tomogram Reconstruction and Segmentation.
10.1 Open etomo package; load GitHub reconstruction settings.
10.2 Load raw data files; select processing device.
10.3 Load tomogram into Amira software.
10.4 Use Cylinder Correlation tool to start calculation.
10.5 Trace microtubules with Trace Correlation Lines tool.
10.6 Correct microtubule tracks manually.
10.7 Stitch segmented serial sections using SerialSectionAligner.

system_prompt: As an expert in mouse model techniques, specializing in psoriasis research, demonstrate hierarchical step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step coordination while adhering strictly to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To induce psoriasis-like inflammation in mice via epicutaneous mannan application. Available materials: mannan powder, incomplete Freund’s adjuvant (IFA), BALB/c female mice, phenobarbital, PBS, IMQ cream, paraformaldehyde, ethanol, paraffin oil, H&E staining reagents. How to prepare mannan stock, apply to mice, monitor inflammation, and perform histological analysis?
output: 1. Introduction to Mannan-Induced Skin Inflammation.
1.1. Epicutaneous application of 50uL of mannan mixture with incomplete Freund’s adjuvant at the back of the BALB/c female mice for three days induces psoriasis-like skin inflammation.
1.2. Monitoring skin redness, scales, and thickness daily for 7–9 days or until the inflammation subsides using the scoring protocol described in Support Protocol 1 is essential.
1.3. Before starting any animal experiment, apply for and get valid ethical permits from ethical review boards of respective institutions/regions.
2. Preparation of Mannan Stock Solution.

2.1. Dissolve the mannan powder (5°g/vial) by gently adding 2°mL of sterile PBS and then transfer all the contents into a 50mL centrifuge tube, adding another 48°mL of PBS to get a 100 mg/mL concentration.
2.2. Aliquot and label the mannan solution in sterile 10mL tubes and freeze them at -20°C until used.
2.3. Note: Mannan solution at 100 mg/mL concentration is stable for over 12 months if stored at -20°C.
3. Epicutaneous Application of Mannan for Psoriasis Induction.
3.1. To get consistent results, 8–12-week-old BALB/c female mice (5–10 mice/group) from specific pathogen-free breeding centers are required.
3.2. Acclimatize the mice for at least one week before starting the experiment.
3.3. Preparation of Mice.
3.3.1. Use at least five mice per cage in a climate-controlled environment with 12:12h light/dark cycles; provide food and water ad libitum.
3.3.2. Use mice epicutaneously treated with PBS on the back, similarly to the mannan application (minimum five mice), for control.
3.4. Mannan Application.
3.4.1. Thaw 1°mL of mannan-PBS solution, previously stored in the freezer, at room temperature for 15 min.
3.4.2. Remove the hair from the mouse skin at the back (2.0 cm×3.5 cm area) first by using a small mouse shaver.
3.4.3. Use the hair removal cream to remove the remaining hair from the specified area of the mouse skin.
3.4.4. Accurately weigh the mice and give an intraperitoneal injection of 80 mg/mL phenobarbital-normal saline solution to anesthetize mice.
3.4.5. Mix 100°uL of mannan-PBS solution (50 mg/mL) with IFA 100uL) and apply mannan + IFA mixture for each mouse.
3.5. Scoring of Psoriasis Lesions.
3.5.1. Score the psoriasis lesions daily by following Support Protocol 1.
3.5.2. Note: The disease progression and scoring start 48°h after mannan treatment for the first time and should be monitored every 24°h for 9 days.
4. Histological Staining of Psoriasis Skin.
4.1. Cut a specified area (2 cm×3.5 cm) of the mouse skin and prepare for the histology.
4.2. Fix the skin by submerging it in 4% paraformaldehyde for 24°h at 4°C.
4.3. Dehydrate the skin tissues in different concentrations of alcohol for 12°h using Support Protocol 2.
4.4. Embed the dehydrated skin in paraffin using 1 cm×1 cm skin pieces in a plastic paraffin-embedding cassette.
4.5. Cut the tissue into 8 um sections using a tissue microtome at room temperature.
4.6. Stain the skin sections with H&E by using Support Protocol 3.
5. Support Protocol 1: Psoriasis Area and Severity Index (PASI) Scoring Protocol.
5.1. Gently take each mouse from its cage and observe the back of the mice for psoriasis progression.
5.2. Evaluate the redness using a 0–4 scale for mannan and PBS-applied mice during disease.
5.3. Evaluate the scales using a 0–4 scale for mannan and PBS-applied mice during disease.
5.4. Measure the skin thickness with a caliper daily.
5.5. Choose the same place and angle on the skin for measuring thickness, using a digital vernier caliper.
6. Support Protocol 2: Dehydration of Skin Tissues.
6.1. Dehydrate the skin samples as follows.
6.1.1. Dehydrate in 50% ethanol for 60 min.
6.1.2. Dehydrate in 70% ethanol for 120 min.
6.1.3. Dehydrate in 80% ethanol for 120 min.
6.1.4. Dehydrate in 90% ethanol for 90 min.
6.1.5. Dehydrate in 95% ethanol for 90 min.
6.1.6. Dehydrate in 95% ethanol for 30 min.
6.1.7. Dehydrate in 100% ethanol for 40 min.
6.1.8. Dehydrate in 100% ethanol for 30 min.
6.1.9. Rehydrate the skin sections in xylene solution with two changes for 10 min each.
6.1.10. Immerse the skin sections in 75 °C paraffin oil with two changes for two hours each.
7. Support Protocol 3: H&E Staining of Skin Samples.
7.1. Submerge the skin samples in each solution as described below.
7.1.1. Deparaffinize the skin sections in xylene solution with two changes for 10 min each.
7.1.2. Rehydrate them in absolute ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.3. Rehydrate them in 95% ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.4. Rehydrate them in 85% ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.5. Rehydrate them in 75% ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.6. Wash the slides in flowing water for 3 min.
7.1.7. Stain the slides with Mayer’s hematoxylin solution for 8 min.
7.1.8. Wash the slides in running tap water for 5 min.
7.1.9. Counterstain the slides using 0.2% eosin in PBS for 2 min.
7.1.10. Dehydrate the slides in 75% ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.11. Dehydrate the slides in absolute ethanol for 5 min.
7.1.12. Treat the slides with xylene solution, two changes for 5 min each.
7.1.13. Mount the slides with a xylene-based mounting medium.
8. Support Protocol 4: Measurement of Epidermal Thickness.

8.1. Measure the thickness of the epidermis under an Eclipse upright optical microscope using Image-pro plus (Nikon, Japan) in at least five different tissue areas to measure the thickness accurately.
8.2. For measuring epidermal thickness, open Image-pro plus 6.0 software and select the line tool.
8.3. Draw a line of unit length on the ruler.
8.4. Select Analyze ongrightarrow Set Scale.
8.5. Enter the length of the line drawn in the known distance, the unit of the length in input unit, check the Global checkbox (use this standard format for all pictures) and click OK.
8.6. Select the length to measure based on the line in the picture.
8.7. Choose at least three images from three different mice for mannan-induced psoriasis skin.
8.8. Choose 10 places to estimate the size of the epidermis.
8.9. Use similar protocols for PBS and IMQ groups as well.
8.10. Obtain at least 30 measurements for the epidermis from each group.
8.11. Analyze the difference between groups using an unpaired t -test.
8.12. Press Ctrl+M (Measurement) to display the results in the results window.
8.13. Use GraphPad Prism, version 5, to analyze the data.
8.14. Use at least five sections from one mouse, and five mice per group, for measurements.
8.15. Measure the thickness of skin sections from psoriasis and naïve mice skin sections in parallel.
8.16. Blindly take the measurements to avoid experimenter bias, and the thickness values can be expressed as mean pmSEM.

system_prompt: As a Cell Biology & Culture expert specializing in human Schwann cell culture and quality control, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To assess the identity, differentiation stages, and function of in vitro cultured human Schwann cells (hSCs) using image-based bioassays. Available materials: HP medium, D-PBS, fixation solution, methanol, Triton X-100, blocking solution, antibodies (NGFR, O4, anti-mouse IgM), AlexaFluor488-conjugated secondary antibodies, FM4-64FX, 1-heregulin, forskolin, EdU, CPT-cAMP, SA-β-Gal assay kit. How to analyze identity, purity, bioactivity, and passage-dependent senescence of hSC cultures?
output: 1. Protocol 1: Analysis of Identity and Purity.
1.1. Cell Plating.
1.1.1. Prepare a single-cell suspension of hSCs, count the cells, and estimate their viability.
1.1.2. Plate the cell suspensions at mid-density in HP medium inside a 24-well plate using 50,000 cells/well or an equivalent density.
1.1.3. Culture the cells in the CO2 incubator for 24-72 hours to obtain a culture at 40%-60% confluence.
1.2. Live Cell Immunolabeling.
1.2.1. Add a sufficient volume of conditioned medium containing NGFR or O4 antibodies to the cells.
1.2.2. Incubate the cells at room temperature for 20 minutes and leave them undisturbed inside the biosafety cabinet.
1.2.3. Remove the conditioned medium and quickly wash the cells 2× with an excess of D-PBS to eliminate unbound antibodies.
1.3. Immunolabeling of Fixed Cells.
1.3.1. Gently aspirate the culture medium, fix the cells for 20 minutes with fixation solution, and wash them 3× with D-PBS.
1.3.2. Permeabilize the cells by incubation with cold methanol or 0.1% Triton X-100 in D-PBS for 10 minutes.
1.3.3. Add blocking solution for at least 30 minutes at room temperature.
1.4. Labeling of Myelin Debris.
1.4.1. Perform a live staining of the cell cultures using anti-O1 antibodies following the protocol described for anti-O4.
1.4.2. Fix the cells with fixation solution and prepare a labeling solution containing AlexaFluor488-conjugated anti-mouse IgM antibodies in combination with FM4-64FX or FluoroMyelinTM.
2. Protocol 2: Authentication of hSC Cultures.
2.1. Introduction to Authentication.
2.1.1. Authentication is performed to correctly identify the cell material by a series of established methods.
2.1.2. A similar guide for cultured hSCs has not yet been developed, but state-of-the-art technologies like RNAseq can determine the constitution of cell cultures.
2.2. Quick Staining Protocols for hSC Validation.
2.2.1. Plate cells from a mixed culture or unknown source as described in Protocol 1A.
2.2.2. Gently aspirate the culture medium, fix the cells for 20 minutes with fixation solution, and wash them 3× with D-PBS.
2.2.3. Permeabilize the cells by incubation with cold methanol and add blocking solution for at least 30 minutes at room temperature.
3. Protocol 3: Analysis of Bioactivity.
3.1. Determination of β1-heregulin/ErbB-elicited ERK and Akt Activation.
3.1.1. Plate the cells as explained in Protocol 1A and starve them of mitogenic factors.
3.1.2. Induce ERK and Akt activation by stimulating the cells with recombinant 1-heregulin.
3.1.3. Incubate the cells for 10 minutes in a CO2 incubator and rapidly remove the medium by gentle aspiration.
3.2. Determination of Heregulin-Dependent Proliferation with and without Forskolin.
3.2.1. Plate the cells as described in Protocol 1A and starve them of mitogenic factors.
3.2.2. Stimulate the cells with 1-heregulin and forskolin, and label the newly synthesized DNA with the thymidine analog EdU.
3.2.3. Incubate the cells in a CO2 incubator for 48–72 hours and fix the cells and detect DNA-bound EdU.
3.3. Determination of cAMP-Dependent Differentiation.
3.3.1. Plate the cells in HP medium as explained in Protocol 1A.
3.3.2. Replace the HP medium with an equal volume of D1 or LP medium containing vehicle or CPT-cAMP.
3.3.3. Incubate the cells in a CO2 incubator for 3–5 days with daily observations to identify morphological changes.
3.4. Determination of Passage-Dependent Senescence.
3.4.1. Plate the cells in HP medium as explained in Protocol 1A.
3.4.2. Incubate the cells in a CO2 incubator for at least 24 hours to ensure all cells are well-adhered and extend processes on the substrate.
3.4.3. Fix the cells with fixation solution and reveal the enzymatic activity of SA-β-Gal by following the manufacturer's recommendations.

system_prompt: As an expert in immunological techniques specializing in the isolation and analysis of B-cell progenitors from bone marrow using flow cytometry, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/equipment coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/equipment continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To isolate and analyze B-cell progenitors from bone marrow using flow cytometry. Available materials: mice, 70% ethanol, ACK lysis buffer, wash buffer, anti-FC blocking antibody, antibodies for CD11B, B220, IgM, and CD19, counting beads. How to euthanize mice, isolate femur, prepare bone marrow, stain B-cells, perform flow cytometry, and analyze data?
output: 1. Euthanize the Mice and Isolate the Femur.
1.1 Euthanize the mice with CO2 under standard protocol 17 or to the specifications of the users' mouse facility.
1.2 Pin the mouse onto a foam board with needles in a supine position.
1.3 Spray the mouse with 70% ethanol.
1.4 Make an incision on the hind leg and extend it from foot to groin.
1.5 Pull the skin to the back and cut it to expose the muscle.
1.6 Carefully remove the muscle with scissors from knee joint to groin joint.
1.7 Cut the knee joint and groin joint with scissors.
1.8 Isolate the femur containing the kneecap and femoral head.
1.9 Remove extra muscle tissue with Kimwipes.
1.10 Repeat with second hind leg to isolate two femurs in total.
1.11 Discard mouse carcass according to UC Davis IACUC protocol #21828.
2. Bone Marrow Isolation.
2.1 Puncture the bottom of a 0.5mL microcentrifuge tube by hand from the inside of the tube with an 18G needle and place it into a 1.5mL microcentrifuge tube.
2.2 Cut both ends of the femur with scissors and place them in the 0.5mL tube.
2.3 Centrifuge the tube at 2,000×g for 10s at RT.
2.4 Discard the 0.5mL centrifuge tube.
2.5 Resuspend the bone marrow cells with ACK lysis buffer for 2min at RT.
2.6 Centrifuge the cells at 500×g for 5min at RT.
2.7 Throw away the supernatant, resuspend the cells with 1 mL of wash buffer, and filter the cells through the mesh net.
2.8 Count the cells.
3. B-Cell Staining.
3.1 Prepare antibody staining solutions.
3.2 Pipette the cell suspension obtained after isolation into individual sample tubes.
3.3 Adjust the volume with wash buffer to 100uL/sample.
3.4 Add 10uL of anti-FC blocking antibody to each staining tube.
3.5 Add 10uL of prepared antibody solution for CD11B, B220, IgM, and CD19 to all experimental samples and the relevant control tubes.
3.6 Incubate in the dark for at least 1h.
3.7 Centrifuge the sample at 1,000×g for 2min at RT.
3.8 Wash twice with 1 mL of wash buffer and resuspend with 490uL of wash buffer.
3.9 Add 10uL of counting beads before flow cytometry.
4. Flow Cytometry Operation.
4.1 Set laser voltages using the no stain sample.
4.2 Perform flow cytometry with single-color-stained samples to compensate fluorochrome emission overlap.
4.3 Run and record all samples, including all controls, after compensation adjustment.
5. Data Analysis using FlowJo Software.
5.1 Gate the beads and the cells.
5.2 Gate on live large cells using the forward and side scatter channels.
5.3 Distinction between myeloid vs. lymphoid cells.
5.4 Distinction between pre-pro B cells and later stages.
5.5 Pro-, small pre-, and large pre-B cells are distinguished based on IgM expression.
5.6 Pro-, small pre-, and large pre-B cells are distinguished between levels of CD43 expression.
5.7 Mature recirculating B cells have downregulated CD43 expression.
5.8 Immature B cells that express a functional surface BCR and are migrating to secondary lymphoid organs have downregulated CD43 expression.

system_prompt: As a Neuroscience Methods expert specializing in electrical stimulation protocols for axon regeneration following peripheral nerve injury, demonstrate multi-level step decomposition, parameter inheritance, and cross-step reagent/instrument coordination while maintaining strict adherence to experimental specifications.
instruction: Structure the protocol into hierarchical operational steps with parameter inheritance. Use imperative verbs, maintain tense consistency, and ensure reagent/instrument continuity across steps. Exclude theoretical explanations. Format steps as: [MainStep] [SubStep] [SubSubStep] with numeric identifiers.
input: To enhance axon regeneration following peripheral nerve injury using electrical stimulation. Available materials: silicon tubing, Cooner wire, Sylgard, surgical instruments, fibrinogen, thrombin, silastic sheeting. Available instruments: stereoscope, LED tester, grass stimulator, confocal microscope. How to build the cuff, prepare for surgery, perform nerve surgery, and post-surgery procedures?
output: 1. Cuff Building.
1.1. Prepare Silicon Tubing.
1.1.1. Take approximately 1 inch of silicon tubing.
1.1.2. Insert the tubing onto a wooden applicator held by a holder.
1.1.3. Under a stereoscope, cut a slit halfway through the tubing.
1.2. Make Holes in the Tubing.
1.2.1. Using a 30G needle, make a hole (1) approximately 4-5 mm from the slit on the left side of the tubing.
1.2.2. On the right side of the tubing, make a superior hole (2) at 2-3mm from the slit.
1.2.3. Make an inferior hole (3) at 2-3 mm below the superior hole 2.
1.2.4. Make another hole (4) leaving 2-3cm distance from 1 on the left.
1.2.5. On the right view, make a superior hole (5), leaving 2-3cm distance from 2, and an inferior hole (6) (below 5) leaving 2-3mm from the superior hole 5.
1.3. Prepare Cooner Wire.
1.3.1. Take approximately 30cm of Cooner wire.
1.3.2. De-insulate approximately 4-5cm in length of the tip of the wire.
1.3.3. Thread 20cm of silk thread into the eye of a #9 sewing needle.
1.3.4. Tie a knot on the de-insulated section of the fine wire with the silk thread.
1.4. Assemble the Cuff.
1.4.1. Pass the silk thread through hole 1 (left) and then through hole 2 (right).
1.4.2. Turn the needle 180° and pass it through hole 3 on the right and then out through hole 1 on the left of the tubing again.
1.4.3. Repeat the process with another 30cm of Cooner wire, and thread it through hole 4 on the left through to the corresponding two holes 5 and 6 on the right.
1.4.4. The remaining de-insulated wire that comes out of the left hole is tightly coiled 4–5 times around the insulated wire.
1.5. Seal the Cuff.
1.5.1. Mix 0.8g of Sylgard 184 silicone elastomer base with 0.1g of Sylgard 184 silicone elastomer curing agent.
1.5.2. Use this mixture to seal any non-insulated metallic fine wire that is outside the cuff tubing.
1.6. Test the Cuff.
1.6.1. Trim the cuff to 1cm in length.
1.6.2. Test the cuff (bubble test) using a LED tester that is maintained at 15V.
2. Surgical Preparation.
2.1. Sterilize Instruments.
2.1.1. Sterilize all surgical instruments in a glass bead sterilizer maintained at 250°C for 30s.
2.1.2. Cool the surgical instruments at room temperature for at least 5 minutes.
2.2. Prepare Surgical Site.
2.2.1. Place heating pad or circulator under a surgical board to maintain body heat.
2.2.2. Place the nose cone on the surgical board and secure it with surgical tape.
2.3. Prepare Fibrinogen and Thrombin.
2.3.1. Thaw out aliquots of thrombin at room temperature.
2.3.2. Prepare fibrinogen by mixing 10mg of fibrinogen with 100uL of distilled water.
2.4. Anesthetize the Animal.
2.4.1. Weigh the animal and place it in the induction chamber to induce anesthesia.
2.4.2. Place the animal on the surgical board with its nose fitted to a nose cone.
2.5. Prepare the Animal for Surgery.
2.5.1. Clip hair using electric hair clipper starting from hip to ankle of the hindlimb.
2.5.2. Remove all the hair and the first drape from under the animal.
2.5.3. Wipe the hindlimb of the animal with alcohol and betadine in succession for three times each.
3. Nerve Surgery.
3.1. Expose the Sciatic Nerve.
3.1.1. Drape the animal with sterile drape such that only the site of surgery is exposed.
3.1.2. Identify the femur by palpating the skin.
3.1.3. Make a 4cm incision along the length of the femur.
3.2. Isolate the Sciatic Nerve.
3.2.1. Blunt dissect the fascia between the biceps femoris and hamstring muscles.
3.2.2. Using #5 forceps, carefully isolate the sciatic nerve from the underlying connective tissues.
3.3. Wrap the Cuff Around the Sciatic Nerve.
3.3.1. Wrap the cuff around the sciatic nerve such that the nerve is in contact with the de-insulated wire inside the cuff.
3.3.2. Connect the de-insulated wires at the distal tip of the cuff to the amplifier box.
3.4. Stimulate the Nerve.
3.4.1. Using a grass stimulator, stimulate the nerve for 1h at 20Hz.
3.4.2. Stimulating the nerve immediately prior to transection allows for visual confirmation of stimulation.
3.5. Transect the Nerve.
3.5.1. Place a small 4mm square of silastic sheeting under the nerve.
3.5.2. Apply fibrin glue consisting of thrombin and fibrinogen to the sciatic nerve.
3.5.3. Completely transect the nerve with sharp micro scissors.
3.6. Suture the Muscles and Skin.
3.6.1. Apply fibrin glue again for 1–2 min.
3.6.2. Without disturbing the transected nerve, suture the muscles using absorbable suture and the skin using non-absorbable nylon suture.
4. Post-Surgery.
4.1. Recover the Animal.
4.1.1. Remove the animal from the nose cone and place it into a clean recovery cage.
4.1.2. Once the animal is ambulatory, administer oral analgesic meloxicam.
4.2. Euthanize the Animal.
4.2.1. Two weeks after nerve transection, inject the animal with 0.3-0.4mL of euthanasia solution.
4.2.2. Following euthanasia, dissect the sciatic nerve from the animal.
4.3. Fix and Image the Nerve.
4.3.1. Fix the nerve in 1mL of 4% PFA for 1h at room temperature.
4.3.2. Place the nerve on a clean slide and add a few drops of Vectashield with DAPI.
4.3.3. Image the nerve using Nikon AR125 HD confocal microscope.
